Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 11:14PM AnnNYC wrote: jkayr -- I think you should definitely go to a breast surgeon, not a general surgeon.  If Mayo isn't too far from you, I think it's best to go to a place like that where specialists treat a LOT of patients with breast cancer.  When a doctor does a LOT of a certain kind of operation, the doctor is better at doing it.  This is called "procedure volume" -- and it is associated with better outcomes for any type of surgery. Plus, I think a place like Mayo is likely to have a good "team" approach between breast surgeon, plastic surgeon, radiology oncologist, medical oncologist. Wherever you go for surgery should be a place where they do the Sentinel Node Biopsy (SNB) -- even if you were Stage 1 you should have this.  They inject your breast with a radioactive dye close to the tumor, and then they can tell which is the first lymph node "in line" -- they biopsy that node.  This means they usually don't have to take as many nodes as in years past.  (If you already know this, I apologize -- I didn't know about it when I was diagnosed -- and I'm just concerned that a general surgeon in a smaller-town hospital might not have the capability to perform the SNB.  If they can't offer it, that's yet another reason to go to a bigger place.) I'm so sorry you had to "join our club" -- but I wish you all the best of luck from here on, Ann

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 11:18PM AnnNYC wrote: hi Barbara -- I'm wondering where you're located? I bet if you name the geographic area, dozens of us will PM you with referral suggestions... I hope your primary has some other recommendations. I can see not canceling your MRI and biopsy appointments while you try to make other appointments -- but these procedures also require skill in performance and interpretation, so you do need to have confidence in the providers. The surgeon you saw -- is he a breast oncologic surgeon?  That is the type of doctor you should be seeing.  Does he practice in a group?  Was his office in some kind of breast cancer services unit?  Ideally, you should be at a place that provides comprehensive breast cancer service, which would include a social worker or nurse practitioner or other patient education person who would be available to you from Day 1.  The fact that none of this seemed apparent to you at the place you went to -- strengthens my inclination to say you are right in never wanting to go back there.  Maybe your primary can tell you whether any such resources are available at the place she referred you to -- or at any other facility in your area. If there is a "breast center" at the hospital you went to, maybe you can find the patient rep person who is supposed to be the human face, and you will be reassured about the hospital. I guess keep your MRI and biopsy appointments, but vigorously search for other options.  If your biopsy at the "bad" place is scheduled for next week, but some other highly-rated place can get you in two weeks after that, I wouldn't think those 2 extra weeks are such a big deal -- it just depends which would be more stressful for you: going someplace you feel bad about, or waiting 2 more weeks.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 11:10AM - edited Apr 24, 2009 11:11AM by AnnNYC Cherneski, I just wanted to say that I had a unilateral mastectomy, with immediate placement of a tissue expander (TE) for reconstruction.  I had been a smoker, and my plastic surgeon asked me (very sweetly and non-judgmentally) if I would try not to smoke for 3 weeks before and after surgery, which I was able to do, and I healed very well.  Then I had a very quick surgery 7 months later to swap the tissue expander for silicon implant.  It's two years since my mastectomy, and I'm quite happy with the result.  I think that many plastic surgeons will do TE/implant reconstruction for smokers, because it is not microsurgery. With the DIEP and TRAM surgeries, there is microscopic suturing of blood vessels, which is why smoking makes these surgeries "iffier."  But since you are having a mastectomy anyway -- if you want TE/implant reconstruction, that kind of reconstruction will not add much time or complexity (and no microsurgery) to the mastectomy that you're having anyway. Just a thought -- TE/implants might be an option for you, if it would be what you want. Whatever you decide, I'm sending you best wishes and hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 10:11AM AnnNYC wrote: Pam, I had declining energy after my unilateral mast with tissue expander recon.  Felt much worse at 3 weeks than I did at 1!!!  For me, I think it was the antibiotic I was taking -- Levaquin.  I took it for 4 weeks, because my drain kept putting out so much fluid that my drain was in for 4 weeks.  I started to improve after drain was out and Levaquin stopped, but it still took me a while to get back to where I was 2 weeks after surgery! But mostly what I felt was fatigue, weakness, joint pain.  I don't remember chills.  I didn't have extreme shortness of breath. The possible side effects of oxycodone include weakness ("asthenia") and chills (as well as nausea and headache, which you also mentioned).  But if you're in pain, you're not supposed to take aspirin or NSAIDs with Plavix, so if your pain is still severe, I guess oxycodone is the option?  Still, I would review all this with your PCP -- she might work out a test withdrawal from the oxycodone to see if that helps, and have ideas about other pain control options that are possible while taking Plavix. Sorry you're feeling so bad -- I'm really glad they ruled out a clot, so I hope there's a way they can figure out to get you feeling better. Hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2011 05:53PM AnnNYC wrote: Rockym, I remember that feeling oh so well.  It is bizarre how it hits out of the blue -- but I think it's good that a lot of the time it's not there.  I hope your counseling session goes well.  Good luck with the MRI -- I think I should caution you that MRIs are extremely sensitive, which is good because they don't miss much, but not so good in that they turn up a lot of "false positives" -- things that look suspicious and then are biopsied but turn out to be benign.  I had this experience after my IDC was diagnosed by an excisional biopsy.  My breast surgeon (BS) then recommended MRI of both breasts, which showed something "suspicious" in the "good" breast -- I had a second MRI with MRI-guided biopsy of that suspicious spot and spent quite a week waiting to hear the result -- which was benign.  I don't know if it's helpful for you to know this, but I hope so!  I'm so sorry you're going through all this, but after they do all the testing and you actually have a definite plan, it should feel a lot less surreal. Hugs, and fingers crossed for good results, Ann

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2011 10:44PM AnnNYC wrote: Rockym, the IDC I did have did not show up on mammogram or ultrasound both because I have dense breasts and because it was in the areola, which the mammo/US doctors said was an area "very hard to visualize" on mammo or US.  It was a painful lump that I felt, and the mammo doctor and BS felt it too, so the BS proceeded with a fine needle biopsy ("inconclusive") and then excisional biopsy (would have been called "lumpectomy" if they'd known it was cancer going in).  Right at that time, a paper in some medical journal was making a big splash, recommending MRI of the "contralateral breast" whenever BC was dx'd in one breast.  In my case, since I had a cancer that hadn't been seen by mammo/US, my BS recommended MRI so nothing would be missed.  Anyway, the right breast turned out okay -- but the tumor excised from the left (0.9 cm IDC, plus more DCIS) hadn't had clean margins and extended into the nipple so I had left mastectomy and SNB at that time (6 weeks after original lumpectomy). Good times!  Not... but this board really, really helped me through, just the support of knowing others were making it through this! We really do have some similar stats -- I wish you nothing but benign from here on out!!!  I'll look for your updates -- fingers crossed!

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 06:56PM AnnNYC wrote: Phoenixsmom, I don't think you're wrong to be concerned about lung cancer risks from radiation. As another ex-smoker, reports about lung cancer risk from radiation stick in my mind: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18202415 That's a link to an abstract of a study published in 2008, showing that women who had ever smoked and had postmastectomy radiotherapy (PMRT) for breast cancer had nearly 19 times the risk of lung cancer as "never-smokers" in the general population.  "Ever-smokers" who didn't have PMRT had nearly 6 times the risk of lung cancer as "never-smokers" in the general population. So it looks to me like PMRT increases the lung-cancer risk that any smoker has by three-fold. I don't know how that compares to your BC recurrence-risk stats, but the lung cancer stats do seem significant.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 04:33PM - edited Jan 25, 2008 04:38PM by AnnNYC Jen, I am glad so many stage 4 women have jumped in to talk to you. I hope you take their words to heart, and get the best treatment you can. What I have to say is about the other "option" you asked about ("should I do nothing and have a better time in months I have left?") -- I don't think that is an accurate option. This is based on seeing the experience of a friend who chose no treatment at all, other than palliative care -- but her last months were VERY difficult. She really didn't have time to have any "good times."   I think there is an occasional misconception that "no treatment" leads to a better quality of life in whatever time one has left.  But I think that is a misconception. The unchecked progression of cancer usually doesn't provide a good quality of life.  Most people just don't see untreated cancer these days, so they don't know that.  I think today's chemo and other treatments extend life AND its quality, for the most part.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 06:32PM - edited Jun 21, 2008 06:49PM by AnnNYC Hi AMANN, I see you have asked this question a few times -- I guess maybe no one here has experience with thalassemia minor and chemotherapy. I do think you deserve more input from your doctors.  Like you say, it's not just a question of what you would "prefer" to do. Do you see a hematologist for your thalassemia?  If so, can that doctor give you some input? Maybe the Thalassemia Foundation would be helpful? http://www.thalassemia.org/ I didn't find anything about chemo on their website, but I did find a Patient Services Department.  They say "The Patient Services Department is here to serve you. If you have a question or a problem, please don't hesitate to contact us at (800) 522-7222." (It's called the Cooley's Anemia Foundation patient services dept, and I know that's major thalassemia -- but they have info about beta/minor thalassemia on the website too, so maybe they can help you.  They say they offer "Physician Referrals: contact information on hematologists located throughout the US who are familiar with thalassemia; contact information on the 6 major thalassemia treatment centers in the US and their satellite hospitals.") I found contradictory statements in the medical literature about chemotherapy in people with minor thalassemia. I found a 2007 report from Sicily (where 6% of the population has thalassemia minor) - the doctors looked at the records of 26 patients with thalassemia minor who had chemotherapy for solid tumors.  55% of the patients had worsening anemia with chemo.  Two needed transfusions.  It recommends treatment with drugs called epoietins - but in the U.S. epoietins (Procrit, Aranesp) now have a warning that they can increase tumor growth and worsen survival rates after chemo. [So, if chemo meant I would have to take epoietins, I might decide not to take chemo.  But, if I felt that I needed chemo to reduce recurrence risk, I guess transfusions would be a safe option if needed for anemia, especially if donors were lined up in advance -- can you discuss the what-ifs with your oncologist?  If your oncologist can't be available to discuss how they would treat worsening anemia in case that happened to you -- then I would really seek out a second opinion from an oncologist.] A report from back in 1997 said chemo IMPROVED the anemia in 2 of 4 breast cancer patients with minor thalassemia.  It studied 245 patients with Stage 2 breast cancer who received chemotherapy.  Four of them had thalassemia minor.  Two of the thalassemia patients had their anemia improve after chemo; and all 4 thalassemia patients had better hemoglobin after chemo than the non-thalassemia women.  Of course, 4 women with thalassemia minor is a very small sample, so it's hard to draw a conclusion. http://sarcomaca.asco.org/ASCO/Abstracts+&+Virtual+Meeting/Abstracts?&vmview=abst_detail_view&confID=30&abstractID=4352 I don't know if this info is helpful to you -- I think you are in a small subset, so maybe being in touch with a thalassemia group or doctor might increase your chances of hearing from someone else with thalassemia who has undergone chemo. Hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 02:47PM - edited Jan 26, 2008 02:48PM by AnnNYC Lots of women have chemo before surgery, in order to shrink the size of tumors and enhance the possibility of getting clean margins. Others here may have more expertise to judge what your surgeon is saying -- but it seems "off" to me, especially given that your radiologist and oncologist disagree with surgeon.  Is your surgeon a breast oncologic specialist?  Are you being seen in a specialized cancer center? This definitely sounds like a time to get a second opinion.  Also, it sounds like the surgeon is not part of a "team" with your radiologist and oncologist -- I think it would be preferable to have more of a "team" working with you. When the surgeon says there's a  "50% chance" that you have another malignant tumor -- is he talking about the spot on the MRI?  In that case, "50%" does not sound scientific, but instead like some vernacular scare tactic that I would not want from a doctor. Did you get MRI of both breasts? (I think that should be part of your general workup as you wait for BRCA testing to make your decision, as you indicated was your basic plan.) As part of the process of getting your second opinion, I think you should ask your current surgeon to write up his concerns and recommendations.  I would think he would be happy to do this if his motivation is to provide you with the best care.  In fact, I think he should already have done this and sent it to your oncologist and radiologist.  They should all be putting their plans and recommendations in writing. You can ask for a copy of each doctor's  correspondence/consult letter to be sent to you. just MHO... Ann

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 09:40AM - edited Jan 27, 2008 09:41AM by AnnNYC Well "adjuvant" means something in addition to, that helps out or boosts.   A "secondary" rather than "primary" therapy. The terminology in breast cancer all reflects a very longstanding idea that surgery is the primary therapy. Chemo, rads, hormone treatment (tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitors, oophorectomy), and herceptin are all "adjuvant" therapy. "Neoadjuvant" means "the secondary therapy is given first, before the primary"!!! http://www.breastcancer.org/dictionary/n/neoadjuvanttherapy_t.jsp This hierarchical idea of "primary" and "secondary" isn't absolutely true anymore in a perfect descriptive sense -- as adjuvants become more precise, refined, and effective -- but it's still a useful framework. (But surgeons notoriously have big egos anyway, and it sounds like yours is really invested in surgery being the primary therapy!!!)

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 08:19AM AnnNYC wrote: Good for you, one2 !  It sounds like you gave your surgeon "the old 1, 2" (boxing terminology, a jab followed by a punch)... In your case, this doesn't even really sound like "neoadjuvant chemo" because you already had lumpectomy (with good margins, right?) and SNB (clear). If I understand correctly, onc wants chemo next because your tumors are Her2+ and you had "lymphovascular invasion." Surgeon wants mast because there were 2 tumors, not 1 -- but they were in same quadrant, only 2 cm apart, and presumably of the same type (triple-positive), so according to most current guidelines, this is NOT a definite indication for mast. Surgeon may also want mast because of "spot on MRI" that doesn't show up on PET scan or US.  I'm assuming onc thinks this may be false positive, may shrink to nothing after chemo, and if you want to conserve your breast, it's probably a little too traumatized right now to do an MRI-guided biopsy... so it's okay to wait and see what appears on another MRI after chemo + rads. It's interesting that I wrote "surgeon WANTS mast" -- in other cases I would expect to be writing "recommends" but clearly this guy WANTS it -- I believe he wants it because he thinks you need it, but still...  You deserve someone who is listening to you, who is not hysterical, who is up to date, who knows how to be a team player.

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 06:54AM - edited Aug 11, 2008 07:52AM by AnnNYC Kevin, I will also venture that "cliches" coming from people who are not there every day are annoying because they have a dismissive sound: "you'll be fine", "you're a fighter." What's bad is when those phrases feel like a way to shut a woman up and "fix" the feelings of the person who is saying them.  I think if you're there everyday, and you're listening, and you're saying "I love you" -- then in that context other phrases won't be annoying cliches.  They'll be part of the conversation between you and your wife.  Shortly after my diagnosis, my boyfriend said to me "I won't let anything happen to you" -- and to me that was heavenly.  Others may feel differently, but for me it was very loving and reassuring -- I guess what I'm saying is don't worry too much about the "script" -- actions speak louder than words, it's good to listen, and if you do the actions and the listening, I think you will be speaking from your heart and it will be supportive. You asked "what do I say to her to let her know that I love her and will be with her through all of it?"  I think you could say exactly those words "I love you, and I will be here with you through everything"

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 12:40PM - edited Jul 15, 2009 12:42PM by AnnNYC Hi Anne, I don't have an answer for your question about lung nodules.  But I did look up some papers about surgical removal of the primary breast tumor when the initial diagnosis is Stage IV.  They confirmed my "gut feeling," which is that surgery can be a good thing.  If you don't mind, I'm just going to post the links, and the "punch lines": http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16614878?dopt=AbstractPlus "CONCLUSIONS: Removal of the intact primary tumor for breast cancer patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improvement in metastatic progression-free survival." [Annals of Surgical Oncology, 2006] http://www.springerlink.com/content/w288277372444j36/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18357493 "CONCLUSIONS: Surgical extirpation of the primary tumor in patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improved metastatic progression-free survival when performed more than 3 months after diagnosis. Resection should be planned with the intent of obtaining negative margins." [Annals of Surgical Oncology, 2008] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18438108 "Historically, women who present with metastatic breast cancer are not offered surgical treatment. However, recent reports indicate that surgery may improve outcome. Using a large database of women whom presented with stage IV breast cancer, we compared outcome of patients who had resection of their primary cancer to those who did not.  CONCLUSION: Patients with stage IV breast cancer who had definitive surgical treatment of their primary tumors had more favorable disease characteristics. However, even after adjustment for these characteristics, surgical treatment remained an independent factor associated with improved survival." [Annals of Surgery, 2008]

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 03:27PM AnnNYC wrote: fulloflife, First of all, it's spelled "sentinel" -- not "sentinal." The term "sentinel node biopsy" or "SNB" refers to a relatively new procedure.  Radioactive dye is injected near the primary tumor, and then whichever lymph node (or nodes) has picked up the radioactivity (as detected by Geiger counter) OR has been dyed blue by the radioactive dye (upon visual observation by the surgeon) is/are removed for histopathologic review.  Biopsied.  To see if any cancer cells are in the node(s). This can pretty commonly be anywhere from one to five nodes.  Sometimes no node appears to have received the dye. The rationale for this procedure is: our lymph systems are pretty mysterious, idiosyncratic, individualized.  In the bad old days, doctors would guess, and just sample a bunch of lymph nodes (increasing the risk for lymphedema -- while still "rolling the dice" about whether any of the nodes they DIDN'T remove were in fact cancerous).  (The bad old days include a friend of mine with melanoma in 1994, who had a number of lymph nodes sampled from his groin which were all benign -- but he died of metastatic melanoma in 1998.  It was right around then that I first started to hear of the development of the SNB procedure, originally invented for melanoma, and then quickly adopted for use with breast cancer.) So -- "sentinel node" -- this term coined in about 1998 -- means "the node that we think was first in line for lymph draining from your particular primary tumor, and if that node is benign, we think it's likely that all your nodes are benign." As noted above by Beesie, the sentinel nodes of breast tumors are usually armpit (axillary) nodes. When you found something in a medical dictionary about the left supraclavicular node being "usually indicative of primary carcinoma of thoracic or abdominal organs" -- this is an OLD sign, also called "Virchow's node" because it was described by Rudolf Virchow (the "Father of Pathology") in the 19th century, as "signalling" the possible presence of stomach or lung cancer.  (Also called "Troisier's sign" for a French physician who noticed the same thing.) So. An enlarged left supraclavicular node was recognized in the 19th century to be a sign (or "signal") of advanced stomach or lung (NOT BREAST!) cancer -- back in the days when there was no x-ray, CT or PET scan, gastroscopy, or MRI to notice stomach or lung cancer before it was so advanced that it was messing up your left supraclavicular node. It has NOTHING TO DO with a technique developed in 1998 to try to determine which axillary (armpit) lymph node was first in line ("sentinel") from an individual's breast cancer. Am I yelling, with these capital letters?  YES!!!!!!!!! I "work in the medical field" too -- and I don't know why you're digging yourself deeper and deeper into your mistake.  "Sentinel node" does not mean "malignant."  End of story.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 09:31AM AnnNYC wrote: Cheri, maybe this is too obvious, and not the issue -- but after you empty the drain bulb, are you squeezing most of the air out before you re-close it?  This is necessary to insure suction -- and I was NOT properly instructed about this before I left the hospital!  Or at least that part of the instruction did not register with me! I found that if I tried to fold the empty bulb in half before re-plugging it, that improved suction.  Also, don't let it get more than half full before draining it. If this doesn't help, it sounds like something is defective with the bulb and/or drain tube, and you should call your BS or PS now to fix it.  At some point (I had drain in for 4 weeks  ), my PS gave me a new bulb, and cut an inch or two off the end of the tube before attaching the new bulb. Good luck -- and don't hesitate to call them!  This kind of after-care is part of the surgery "package" -- if the BS or PS can't see you before Friday, at least they should have a skilled nurse in the office who can fix this for you.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 10:20PM AnnNYC wrote: fulloflife, I don't mean to pick on you -- I just want to clarify that even in your post above, when you quote Beesie as saying that 'a sentinel node is the very first lymph node to receive drainage from a cancer-containing area of the breast' (she is correct), you continue to be in error when you say "that defines a metastatic node."  No, it doesn't. Metastatic means that cancerous cells are found elsewhere in the body, outside the primary tumor.  A metastatic node would have cancerous cells in it.  To say that a lymph node receives drainage means it receives lymphatic fluid. To say that a node is "the very first to receive lymphatic fluid from a particular area" does NOT mean the node received cancer cells!  It received lymphatic fluid!  But if it's first in line to receive fluid from the area of a tumor, then it's a good node to test -- if it is not cancerous (i.e., if it is not metastatic) then you can be pretty sure the other nodes further down the line are not cancerous either. The phrases you cite -- yours and Beesie's -- are NOT the same thing "just worded differently." Actually, there are women here who do know a lot -- and actually, sometimes more than a given doctor, which often is an incentive for a woman to find a better doctor.  Certainly, information needs to come from credible sources.  But not every doctor is credible!  (Certainly not the occasional doctor who is unfamiliar with inflammatory breast cancer and tells a 30 year old woman she's too young to have breast cancer, and anyway breast cancer doesn't hurt!)  I wouldn't necessarily characterize the responses you got as "offended" -- unfortunately, you were simply wrong.  Incorrect information will quickly be corrected here, which is a virtue of this kind of website that has been noted in scientific reports.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 06:44PM - edited Feb 20, 2009 06:48PM by AnnNYC Hi June -- your breast surgeon (BS) and/or plastic surgeon (PS) will probably prescribe post-surgery physical therapy for you.  If they don't suggest it, ask them about it when you are consulting prior to surgery.  I wonder if it might be a good idea to see the physical therapist pre-surgery, with your flute, so the PT can see the work you do and map out a plan to get you back in shape to do it. From my own mastectomy experience, I would guess that "rehabbing" your arms and the chest muscles that help you lift and extend your arms to hold the flute would be a bit more of a challenge than breathing.  It really hurt me to take a breath for about 6 hours after mastectomy (maybe 18 hours, but I was kind of drugged by then, so I don't really remember) -- but on the second day, I think that particular pain was all gone -- and in fact they brought me a plastic Spirometer thingie in the hospital, and commanded me to use it for the next two weeks, to prevent pneumonia.  You forcefully exhale and try to suspend a little plastic ball in a tube with your exhalation for as long and as "high" as you can.  This was not at all painful. There are women on this board who have resumed strenuous exercise like weightlifting, karate, rockclimbing. There are mixed reports from musicians.  I have done a search for a lot of previous conversations about musicians, and here they are (if any of these doesn't work as a "hot link", it should work if you copy it and paste it into your browser). http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/84/topic/728534?page=1#post_1223490 http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/7/topic/709344?page=1#post_1029931 http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/73/topic/708194?page=1#post_989680 http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/73/topic/708194?page=1#post_969092 [The last link is to the following comment by Sarah Schm (Sarah Schmalenberger), who ...published an expository article about the "research problem" that generated this Life and Livelihood Study on musicians and breast cancer.  Aptly titled "Life and Livelihood:  Musicians Coping With Breast Cancer," the article is accessible online from the journal Review of Disabilities International - which published a two-issue set of essays on the problems of performing artists.   Find the article at  http://www.rds.hawaii.edu/downloads/ Select from the volumes of RDS articles the first choice, Volume 4 Issue 1, 2008, and look for the title above.] Sarah is a hornist who is currently conducting a study at: http://www.musiciansurvivor.org/ Wishing you the best -- PM me if you want, Ann

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 09:12PM - edited Nov 13, 2011 09:18PM by AnnNYC Hi Miri -- I think my situation was a little similar to yours -- my first biopsy (fine needle aspiration) was "inconclusive" -- so my breast surgeon recommended an excisional biopsy to remove the entire lump (same thing as a lumpectomy, but some doctors only call it a lumpectomy if they know beforehand that it's cancer). Keeping my fingers crossed that your lump turns out to be benign!  In a way, maybe I was a bit like your husband in that I didn't want to look too far ahead -- "I'll cross that bridge when I come to it" was what I told myself -- maybe I was in a bit of denial -- but we're all individual and have to deal with our own feelings in our own way.  I guess I ended up not talking much to anyone in the biopsy process -- because I remember mostly everyone said "I'm sure you'll be fine" and I wasn't sure.  I didn't really want to imagine "what if I'm not?" "what if I need a mastectomy?" (turned out I did) -- but it wasn't helpful when people said "I'm sure you'll be fine" -- in fact, that kind of scared me. Didn't find this Board until 6 months later -- wish I'd found it sooner! Just want to send you hugs and hope -- hope you can take this one step at a time, and hope your "steps" will end with a benign biopsy report -- but whatever step ends up being required, somebody here has had to take it, and will be glad to talk to you about it. Hope that made sense and was at least a teeny bit helpful!  This biopsy stage is a very stressful process, that's for sure!  ((((((Hugs))))))  Ann

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 03:35PM AnnNYC wrote: Erin and Valerie -- This is in regard to Valerie's questioning the need for excisional biopsy: I had an excisional biopsy following a fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy that was inconclusive (which I understand is often the case with FNA, because cells get distorted in appearance).  I have a friend on these boards whose triple negative stage 3 tumor was misdiagnosed for several months as "benign" due to the results of a core needle biopsy.  It doesn't strike me as excessive that a surgeon recommends excisional removal of a discrete lump. Also -- as to whether an excisional biopsy is a more invasive or difficult procedure -- I had an excisional biopsy on my left breast (which showed IDC -- this was the spot that was "inconclusive" by FNA).  A few weeks later I had MRI-guided core needle biopsy on my right breast (turned out to be benign) -- which, in my experience, was far more brutal than the excisional!  My right breast turned entirely purple, and was discolored and painful for weeks!  The site of the excisional biopsy on the left seemed far more "controlled" and easier to recover from. Your mileage may vary. Erin1, after my excisional biopsy, I took only one of the prescribed Tylenol with codeine.  The thing that was most painful for me was any kind of bumpy ride -- if at all possible, I would suggest you avoid those! Good luck -- wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 07:58PM - edited Mar 28, 2008 08:00PM by AnnNYC NancyD -- it was published in 2001 -- so it took them three years to analyze the data, write the paper, and get a journal to publish it.  That seems typical to me. For 22 years (in a medical research department, though not cancer research), I've been the person handling manuscripts, revisions, submissions, more revisions,getting Accounts Payable to pay the page charges (yes, it costs money to publish in most med/sci journals!), getting all the authors to sign their copyright and conflict of interest forms, proofing the galleys...  So I'm guessing 1.5 to 2 years to analyze the data, 3 to 6 months to write the paper (lots of authors on these), 6 months to 1.5 years from submission of a manuscript until it sees the light of day!  And the info is "embargoed" until publication date.  And I bet these authors got a lot of rejection notices saying the results weren't that groundbreaking! One good thing these days (last 3 years or so) is that many journals will now publish papers online "in advance of print publication" -- so even though the paper issue of the journal won't come out until August 2008, for example, an accepted paper can now appear online at least 6 months earlier... Time for a glass of wine!

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 10:32PM - edited Jan 12, 2008 10:34PM by AnnNYC Dear Desny and Shirlann, Last March, there were big news stories about recommendation to do MRI of undiagnosed breast after cancer diagnosis in the other, especially if the diagnosed cancer did not show up on mammogram or ultrasound.  This was based on a study published in the New England Journal of Medicine (http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/short/356/13/1295) and was issued as a recommendation by the National Cancer Institute (http://www.cancer.gov/newscenter/pressreleases/MRIContralateralRelease) I had MRI done of my opposite (right) breast -- the newspapers were full of this recommendation starting on March 27 -- I think my surgeon called me on March 28 to set up the MRI!  The MRI found a suspicious spot, which was then biopsied under another MRI (kind of a brutal experience) and turned out to be benign, so I only had left mastectomy.  That's the potential drawback -- lots of false positives on MRI -- but I guess that's better than false negatives on mammo or US.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 02:02AM AnnNYC wrote: Randy, I am so sorry you are your wife are going through this. As geebung and LUVmy2girlZ have indicated, it is not at all unusual to go through these changing steps: aspiration, biopsy, lumpectomy, mastectomy, change of postmastectomy treatment plan. I had a little lump that I felt, it didn't show up on mammo or ultrasound, the fine needle aspiration was inconclusive, the surgeon recommended an excisional biopsy (would have been called a lumpectomy if they knew ahead of time that it was cancer).  Surgeon kept saying "it's probably benign but let's just get it out." Well, it was IDC, with associated DCIS, not clean margins, involving nipple -- so I had to have a mastectomy.  In my case, the mastectomy DID have clean margins, so I didn't need radiation. As frustrating as it is to keep having these other shoes drop -- I think it's a lot better than 40 years ago, when women would go under anesthesia for a biopsy and wake up to find their entire breast and chest muscle removed.  Unfortunately, it can take all these steps for a diagnosis.  The whole process is grueling -- and having to go through it is unfair.  But the many steps, and the changes along the way, stem from 2 good motives: 1) to make sure a correct diagnosis and appropriate treatment are given while 2) trying not to inflict treatment that is more invasive or harsh than the situation requires. And finally, it is so good that you and your wife are clearly such a strong team in dealing with this.  You may think, "of course -- I couldn't be any other way," but not everyone is that way!  Take care, Ann

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 11:35PM AnnNYC wrote: ValerieG, I just have a couple of questions. Is the new tumor in the same breast as the first one? Did you ever have MRI before?  If you didn't have MRI before your original lumpectomy, is it possible your "new" 6 mm tumor was there all along? Were you tested for the gene for the liver enzyme CYP2D6?  This is the enzyme that metabolizes tamoxifen, making it work -- a small percentage of women will have genetic variants that make this enzyme far less active, and therefore tamoxifen is unlikely to be of use. (I am in this small percentage -- since I am postmenopausal, I was switched to aromasin. For premenopausal women who are poor metabolizers of tamoxifen, oophorectomy should be considered.)

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 05:32PM AnnNYC wrote: Catty1, I don't think it is unreasonable to want a biopsy.  A "clear" mammogram cannot rule out inflammatory breast cancer.  IBC imay be relatively rare, but still it accounts for 1 to 5% of all cases of breast cancer, according to the National Cancer Institute.  Given that there are about 230,000 new cases of breast cancer every year in the U.S., that would mean 2,300 to 11,500 new cases of IBC per year.  http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Sites-Types/IBC My main point is, rare or not, IBC is unusually aggressive and fast-moving -- so even though the odds are in your favor that this is not IBC, you are right to want to try to rule out IBC as soon as possible, because a delay in diagnosis for a person who does have IBC would not be good. Fingers crossed for you!

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2009 11:19AM AnnNYC wrote: I sent a PM to the posters, but haven't heard from them. I for one find the "lottery" ("chance to win one of three cash prizes of $250") appalling!  And I've worked on clinical trials and clinical research for about 20 years -- can't imagine the "lottery" would fly at our Institutional Review Board (IRB = U.S. name for "Ethics Board").  All study participants should be treated the same.  I would think this would really skew against enrollment by women with children who were single moms and juggling low-paying jobs -- they have to be realists, and can't spare a trip and time off work to participate in the study based on the "chance" of winning $250.  That just seems so frivolous and demeaning.  Many studies pay $20 simply for completion of a questionnaire...  It seems a study like this ought to be able to compensate women at least $50 for participation, and if it can't afford it, they just shouldn't do it -- because, as I said, I think the current set-up will yield a very skewed enrollment (if any!). Our IRB has to approve all advertising and recruitment materials/flyers/ads/etc. in addition to the study itself.  And after approval, the flyer/ad has to state that it was approved by the IRB.

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 12:32PM - edited Aug 19, 2008 12:32PM by AnnNYC Otter -- how "colloquial" of her ("Mack truck") -- is there no mention of doing ultrasound routinely, given your history?  MRI once in a while?  My IDC was not seen on mammo or ultrasound, so my follow-up is mammo/US of remaining breast once a year, MRI of both breasts (R breast, L silicone implant) once a year, halfway between mammos.  My insurance (United Healthcare) is covering this. My BS ordered mammo/US, but the radiology place kept taking US "off the menu" -- breast surgeon and I tried to order it 4 different times between us, but on the day of my mammo, the tech insisted, "the radiology says there's nothing suspicious on your mammo, so you don't need US."  I said, "Even with my history of BC in the contralateral breast that was never seen on mammo?" Scurry, scurry, scurry.  Whisper, whisper, whisper.  Return: "Get Dr. G (breast surgeon) to order it."  Me: "she has ordered it, about 4 times."  They: "Oh.  Well, we can't fit you into our schedule for US today."  Me, fuming to myself, "but I have only been saying 'plus ultrasound' until I'm blue in the face trying to book this appt for the last 4 months" but I bit my tongue and just said: "Okay, when can you?" So, a week later, I got my ultrasound.  Clear.  (That's good!)  And I'll have MRI in about 6 months. I think that if you would prefer more than annual or semiannual mammo, you could at least call your insurance to see what they'll cover?  Also, maybe your BS or onc has a different imaging protocol in mind than your radiologist (or her staff) does, and if they prescribe it, radiologist and insurance might comply?

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 01:48PM - edited Apr 30, 2010 02:04PM by AnnNYC beckiejoy (and Nikkietara) -- if you can feel a lump, and you can put the doctor's finger on the spot so they can feel it too, then they have something to biopsy. I had a small painful bump at the side of my areola (3 o'clock on the areola of left breast) -- diagnostic mammo and ultrasound showed nothing, but fortunately I had a great radiologist (who specializes in breast imaging and has done thousands upon thousands) who basically said, "you have dense breasts which can make it hard to see a tumor, and the nipple/areola complex is also very hard to visualize with mammo/US -- so we can't see anything, but we can feel the lump, and we don't know what it is, so I'm referring you to a breast surgeon for a biopsy." BS first did a fine needle aspiration (FNA), where they take cells out of the lump through a (duh!) fine needle -- this was "inconclusive" so the BS recommended an excisional biopsy (surgical biopsy, wide excision, would be called a lumpectomy if they knew in advance that it was cancer).  The result of the excisional biopsy is in my signature line: IDC, Stage 1, Grade 2. My experience is not rare -- except maybe in having experienced doctors who recommended the biopsies, instead of me having to push them to do it.  My doctors kept saying, "It's probably benign, but let's make sure" -- and I guess that's what I'm saying to both of you!

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 09:25PM - edited Jan 4, 2008 09:29PM by AnnNYC I felt the lump starting almost exactly a year ago!  Right after New Year's 2007, I had what felt and looked like a little pimple or boil at the outer edge of my left nipple (about "3 o'clock" if you were looking straight at me). It was very painful and red.  It reminded me of plugged milk duct preceding mastitis when I was nursing 23 years earlier. (I had bought a new bra for New Year's Eve and wore it without washing first -- my skin is very sensitive, so I thought maybe it was an allergic reaction to fabric sizing or dye -- and in fact maybe part of the "inflamed" appearance was an allergic reaction, in which case I was really lucky that it made this bump more noticeable.) Well, I didn't act on this immediately, because it really seemed like an allergy or infection, and in fact the redness, heat and pain subsided in a few days -- but the lump didn't. I needed annual mammo anyway -- made appointment, and had mammo on Feb 2.  Mammo normal.  But because I made the radiologist feel the lump (which felt a little "fixed" -- the surface bump felt like a mushroom head on a stalk "anchored" about 1/2 inch below the surface) she did ultrasound also.  Also appeared normal.  But radiologist said, "the nipple/areola can be a difficult area to image -- you should see a breast surgeon who may want to biopsy anyway" and referred me to BS.  That appt was Feb 14 -- what a Valentine's Day -- had fine needle aspiration (FNA) and was told of "abnormal cells" that were probably benign hyperplasia/fibroadenoma, but BS thought it would be wise to perform excisional biopsy to get a better look and remove the lump as it was painful anyway.  Biopsy was March 2.  Surgeon said she would have results for me by March 13, and made appt for that day (a Tuesday).  But on Friday, March 9 -- she left a message on my voicemail saying "call me when you can, I'll be here late." Well, that was scary. I heard the message about 8 in the evening, and called the number she had left.  It was her service, and the first guy I spoke to asked what I was calling about and I said "to get results."  He was snippy and said "We won't relay a message asking for results over the weekend.  She'll see it when she gets in on Monday."  I argued that her message said I should call her anytime over the weekend, and wanted to play it for him...  but he was giving me the classic bitchy "buh-bye"...  So I hung up and immediately dialed back and reached a different person on the service -- didn't mention "results" -- said "Dr. G asked me to speak to her immediately" -- left my number, and BS called me back in 5 minutes. Okay. It's a bit of a blur.  I think she said "It's not benign.  It's a small well-behaved cancer in a bit of a bad location.  But this thing is very fixable."  I said "This may sound superficial, but what I'm really worried about right this second is -- am I going to lose my nipple?"  She said, "That's a legitimate concern.  You're coming to see me on Tuesday and we'll talk about options.  But this is very fixable, and you'll be just fine." Whoa. On Tuesday, she showed me path report, explained to me that margins were not clean, and a lumpectomy would offer me the "worst of both worlds" -- whole point of lumpectomy is to have cosmetically, functionally acceptable breast -- but with the whole nipple/areola complex removed it wouldn't be -- and would necessitate rads and perhaps chemo.  So, suddenly I joined the club, and learned new words like TRAM, DIEP, S-GAP...  chose tissue expander only. About my Ob-Gyn -- I went to see her for annual exam Feb 28 or so, between FNA and excisional bx -- she did breast exam and was the only doctor to find the lump without my laying her finger on it and rolling it around!  She said "Is this what they're gonna biopsy? Yes?  Good!"  She also said, about BS and PS -- even though she hadn't been the one to refer me to them -- that if she was ever in my shoes, she would see the same docs.  That made me feel great.  And she called me after me biopsy to learn dx.  And told me to let her know when mastectomy was scheduled.  And then called me the day of just to say she was thinking of me and wishing me well!  What a doll. (Basil16883 -- I've PM'd you the names of my doctors here in NYC -- I think you can tell I've been very happy with all of them)

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2008 03:48PM AnnNYC wrote: Well -- I just found a 2002 study that says "subareolar injection and subdermal injection elsewhere in the breast usually identify the same sentinel node (SN). Subareolar injection appears to be particularly valuable in patients with multicentric or deep non-palpable breast tumours." And a 2005 paper by the same authors that says: "Superficial lymphatic drainage from the breast most frequently merges to a single axillary lymph node, irrespective of the site of tracer injection. In a few cases different injection sites identify different, often closely interconnected sLNs." So, I am revising my previous "guesses" -- it looks like, even with out localizing dye injection into an identified suspicious area in the right breast, a SNB is pretty likely to identify the actual "sentinel" node, i.e., the one that is first reached by lymph fluid draining from the breast.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 07:35PM - edited Jul 22, 2011 07:36PM by AnnNYC edoyrest, I don't know how old you are, but use of the Oncotype DX test when there are positive nodes is only appropriate for post-menopausal women, according to the website of the only laboratory that performs the test (see http://www.oncotypedx.com/en-US/Breast/HealthcareProfessional/FAQs.aspx): "The Oncotype DX assay is clinically validated for newly diagnosed breast cancer patients who are either: Even in postmenopausal women, the use of Oncotype DX when 1-3 nodes are affected is only about 2 years old.  As of November 2010, the BlueCross-BlueShield Technology Evaluation Center (TEC) said: "use of the 21-gene expression profile (Oncotype DXTM) for selecting adjuvant chemotherapy in patients with lymph-node-positive breast cancer does not meet the TEC criteria."   (see http://www.bcbs.com/blueresources/tec/vols/25/gene-expression-profiling.html )

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 11:47PM - edited Mar 6, 2008 12:14AM by AnnNYC Oh Randie - I'm so sorry you got this diagnosis.  But AnneW is right: "now that you know it's IDC, you have time to breathe, research your options, and get professional opinions." I don't know how close you are to Sacramento, but I've been googling breast cancer treatment Sacramento anyway... 1) Maybe you could try the UC Davis Breast Cancer Center http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/cancer/Specialties/breast.html.  They are one of ONLY 60 places in the whole country designated as a Breast Cancer Center of Excellence by the National Cancer Institute. They also have affiliate centers in Marysville and Merced, and an infusion center (should you end up needing chemo) in Roseville. About making an appointment as a new patient, the website says: "Your doctor may refer you to UC Davis Cancer Center. Or, you may schedule an appointment on your own, if your health insurance plan gives you that flexibility. To make a first appointment, please call the Cancer Center's New Patient Referral Office at (916) 703-5210 or (800) 362-5566." 2) I found a group called "Save Ourselves - The Breast Cancer Organization of Sacramento" (http://www.save-ourselves.org/) They have a 24-hour hotline: 1-800-422-9747 or 916-448-5432.  Maybe someone can recommend a group of breast cancer specialists close to you, or maybe they have other resources that might be helpful to you. 3) On a San Diego State University website (http://qap.sdsu.edu/screening/breastcancer/guide/index.html), you can download a pamphlet about BC that your doctor was legally obligated to give to you!!!  The website says: "The State of California requires that doctors give a copy of  ‘A Woman's Guide to Breast Cancer Diagnosis and Treatment'  to a patient about to have a breast biopsy or who has been diagnosed with cancer. The guide was developed by The California Department of Health Services, Breast Cancer Early Detection Program." Did your doctor give you this booklet when he told you he was sure it was "bad", warned you about possible mastectomy, and asked you to carry your slides to pathology lab yourself? I'm guessing NOT, because page 5 of the booklet says: "Doctors used to believe that it was best to biopsy a woman's lump and remove her breast in the same operation if cancer was found. A woman went into surgery for a biopsy not knowing whether she would wake up with her breast. This rarely happens today. Studies show that it is safe to start treatment within several weeks after your biopsy. This two-step procedure gives you time to:

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 11:30AM AnnNYC wrote: Dyscohesion means the cells aren't sticking together in a normal way.  But what I was told about FNA is that the cells can get distorted passing through the fine needle, so the pathologist can't always tell if an abnormality was caused by the needle passage or not.  So if they see anything not entirely normal, it's best to remove the whole lump.  Wishing you benign results!

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 01:34PM AnnNYC wrote: Ty, my bump looked like the beginning of a big pimple at first, and it was red and sore to the touch.  The first few days that I noticed it, it was even sore WITHOUT touching it.  It really reminded me of a kind of plugged, inflamed feeling I had gotten occasionally while nursing my son 23 years earlier.  I also have a lot of skin allergies and had just worn a new bra without washing first, so I thought it might have been some dermatitis.  The redness and pain decreased after about 5 days (so maybe there was dermatitis, and I was lucky because it drew my attention to the bump?) -- but the bump remained, and it would hurt if I touched it enough.  I would say the part you could see on the surface was as big around as the tip of a Q-tip -- but it didn't stick up very high.  But when I touched it, and moved my finger around while holding on to the top bump, it felt like it was a tiny flowerhead on a stalk that was anchored about half an inch below the surface.  After excisional biopsy and cancer dx, I described that feeling to my surgeon and she said it really matched up almost precisely with the shape of the tumor they found. Well -- enough of that. About mate -- I'd had a "sort-of" boyfriend/"friends with benefits" guy in my life for the previous 9 years.  He really stepped up to the plate for me.  He said "we'll get through this -- I won't let anything happen to you."  He was great when I was discussing reconstruction options (oh, for various reasons, mastectomy ended up being recommended) -- he said, "I need you to BE HERE -- I just want you to do whatever you think is best for your health.  That's what matters to me."  He and I had had a mutual friend, a woman under 40 who opted for holistic/naturopathic treatment for BC in about 1994-1998 -- she died.  I know he was very worried but he really conveyed strength to me.  In what I knew was a reference to our mutual friend, he did say, "Just promise me you'll do everything the Cancer Center doctors recommend.  If you want to go to wheat-grass-juice camp, you can always do that later after you do all the medically recommended treatment." Hope the stories are of some interest to you! Best, Ann

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 02:07PM AnnNYC wrote: Ty, I think people really differ in how much worry they can handle.  I wouldn't worry too much about your husband!  I think he's probably really scared, but trying to tell himself and you NOT to be scared yet -- I think once you have an answer you two will be in sync again.  It's only human to be a little pissed about having to be scared.  Even though it'd be nicer for you if he didn't convey that!  Hopefully, he's just in a momentary feeling that will pass. With my "sort-of" BF and I having a bit of a long-distance relationship, geographically (he lives two hours away) and otherwise (hence, the "sort-of") I didn't really convey much in the way of fear to him until the diagnosis -- but I guess I wasn't really that afraid until then, either.  Fortunately my docs were so pro-active, and moved everything along so fast, while at the same time saying "I think it's probably nothing but I just want to make sure" -- that I didn't HAVE to worry that much myself.  My biggest fear before excisional biopsy was of general anesthesia, and my boyfriend could relate because he's a little phobic about certain things too -- I guess we just fixated on "let's breathe deeply and not be phobic about surgery" and didn't talk about cancer until the pathology report came back.  Ummm... we also used a "recreational" plant whose leaves are smoked... and an occasional shot of tequila.  Others use things like xanax or valium.  I think it's okay to have a little medical (or "self-medicating") assistance in relaxing. Best, Ann

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 12:12PM AnnNYC wrote: Tygress, I'm sorry about lack of response to your earlier questions. About the bump on your areola -- if it does not show up on mammogram or ultrasound, I really think you should ask for it to be biopsied in some way.  The first step would probably be fine needle aspiration (FNA) -- they take some cells with a very thin needle to look at under a microscope. The reason I say this is because the nipple and areola can be "very hard to visualize" with mammo or US -- in the words of the radiologists who did mine -- I had a bump on my areola that everyone could feel.  It didn't show up on mammo or US.  Then I was referred for FNA, which was "inconclusive."  Then my breast surgeon did an excisional biopsy, trying to take out the whole bump -- and it was invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC). Please understand, I'm not saying this to scare you.  More to scare your doctors!  I'm so thankful I had doctors who pushed to get a definitive answer right away -- they could easily have said "let's wait six months and do another mammo" -- and if nothing showed up then, they could have been waiting for years for this to show up on mammo. 80% of biopsies turn out benign, but I just think it's very important to biopsy to make sure. The good news for me was that this was very small and early.  (The other good news, psychologically, was that it DIDN'T show up on mammo, so I didn't have to beat myself up for not having gotten my mammo for 3 years!) Hoping you get the "all-clear" from your doctors, after they thoroughly check this out, Hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 01:26AM AnnNYC wrote: lns2119, I haven't had the wire insertion, although someone on this board who recently had it -- and had been worried about it -- said it was not bad at all. But about removing the entire mass (this is called an excisional biopsy) -- I think it's probably a good idea.  I have had several kinds of biopsies, and for me the surgical excisional biopsy was the LEAST barbaric!  It's very controlled -- it had the least bleeding and bruising.  (MRI-guided biopsy was the WORST!) With a lump that small, the excisional biopsy makes sure they got the right thing, they have plenty of tissue for all tests, and you won't need another biopsy. I think it's very practical of your doctor to do this.  Try not to worry too much -- easier said than done, I know -- but remember, 80% of biopsies come back benign. About telling your children -- I would say it depends on how nervous each of them is and if any is under particular stress themselves (sick child, for example).  But another poster here (iodine) points out that we deny our families the opportunity to be close and really know what's going on with us if we "tough it out" and don't tell them.  You might want to tell your kids "I'm having this test" so that they ARE included. Just my thoughts, Wishing you the best, and b9 results! Ann

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 10:46AM - edited Feb 24, 2008 10:47AM by AnnNYC Nancy, I'm so sorry you're going through this. My experience, too, was that there was a week or two between every visit and test result. 1/1/07 I felt lump 2/2/07 mammo and ultrasound showed nothing, referred to breast surgeon (BS) 2/14/07 BS performed fine needle aspiration (FNA) -- inconclusive, recommended excisional biopsy -- got next available surgical appointment, which was 3/2/07 -- excisional biopsy 3/9/07 -- got biopsy results by phone (Friday evening) - invasive ductal (IDC) 3/13/07 -- talk to BS about plan. Mastectomy (MX) recommended.  MARCH/APRIL -- Meet with PS about recon.  Have another ultrasound and two MRIs (one an MRI-guided biopsy) of other breast to see whether I need bilateral.  Takes forever to get these appointments and results.  Oh yeah, transvaginal ultrasound too to check my ovaries.  FINALLY... 4/16/07 -- left MX, SNB and recon. I worried about the time passing.  They kept saying "no problem."  I guess it's not really a problem, but it is distressing. I'd be interested to hear others' experiences, too. My nodes were entirely clear, Nancy, so in my case it certainly appears that the waiting wasn't a problem -- except for my psyche!! Of course, my surgeon did know on March 9 that my tumor was ER+ PR+ and HER2-negative.  I'd like to think that for someone HER-2 positive or triple-negative, things would have moved along faster.  In fact, maybe my appts moved along at a leisurely pace while my docs WERE prioritizing triple-neg, HER2+, larger tumors -- which is as it should be. If you're feeling changes in your breast, I hope you're calling your doctor and telling him/her -- Good luck to you, Nancy -- please keep us posted. Hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 02:10AM - edited Aug 2, 2008 02:20AM by AnnNYC I always thought of "lesion" as a very generic word that doctors use to mean "something wrong" or "something abnormal." Here is a definition from Dorland's Medical Dictionary: lesion (le´zhәn)   any pathological or traumatic discontinuity of tissue or loss of function of a part. Lesion is a broad term, including wounds, sores, ulcers, tumors, cataracts, and any other tissue damage. They range from the skin sores associated with eczema to the changes in lung tissue that occur in tuberculosis. Dana, in your mom's case, my guess is that they are sure they can identify the "lesions" in her liver as tumors, so they used the word "tumor."  As for bones,as wishiwere and DebC said, what happens with bone mets is often in the nature of erosions, rather than "growths" -- but in any case, the scans showed some abnormal spots.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 04:22PM - edited May 5, 2011 04:33PM by AnnNYC EshLou, I'm not Stage IV -- but the topic of mastectomy in women who are Stage IV has come up on this board previously, and I thought I would post some of the research links that have been posted here previously, a lot of it gathered by members English Major and rkt (Becky). Even if you actually are in Stage IV (which is not clear at all ! ), the idea that mastectomy is of no use to women who are Stage IV may be outdated.  Recent research seems to show improved survival for some women.  I apologize for the length, but thought this may be helpful -- even if you don't go back to your twit-onc, maybe she should read some of this! http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16614878 Babiera GV, et al. Effect of primary tumor extirpation in breast cancer patients who present with stage IV disease and an intact primary tumor.  Annals of Surgical Oncology 2006;13(6):776-782. Reviewed the records of all breast cancer patients treated at M.D. Anderson (Houston, TX) between 1997 and 2002 who presented with stage IV disease and an intact primary tumor. Of 224 patients identified, 82 (37%) underwent surgical extirpation of the primary tumor (segmental mastectomy in 39 [48%] and mastectomy in 43 [52%]), and 142 (63%) were treated without surgery. The median follow-up time was 32.1 months. After adjustment for other covariates, surgery was associated with a trend toward improvement in overall survival (P=.12; relative risk, .50; 95% confidence interval, .21-1.19) and a significant improvement in metastatic progression-free survival (P=.0007; relative risk, .54; 95% confidence interval, .38-.77). CONCLUSIONS: Removal of the intact primary tumor for breast cancer patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improvement in metastatic progression-free survival. Prospective studies are needed to validate these findings. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17522944 Gnerlich J, et al. Surgical removal of the primary tumor increases overall survival in patients with metastatic breast cancer: analysis of the 1988-2003 SEER data.  Annals of Surgical Oncology 2007;14:2187-2194. A retrospective, population-based cohort study by using the 1988-2003 Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program data. Overall survival in women with stage IV disease was compared between women who underwent surgical excision of their breast tumor with women who did not, controlling for potential confounding demographic, tumor- and treatment-related variables, and propensity scores (accounting for variables associated with the likelihood of having surgery). RESULTS: Of 9734 SEER patients with stage IV breast cancer, 47% underwent breast cancer surgery and 53% did not. Median survival was longer for women who had surgery than for women who did not, both among women who were alive at the end of the study period (36.00 vs. 21.00 months; P < .001) and among women who had died during follow-up (18.00 vs. 7.00 months; P < .001). After controlling for potential confounding variables and propensity scores, patients who underwent surgery were less likely to die during the study period compared with women who did not undergo surgery (adjusted hazard ratio, .63, 95% confidence interval, .60-.66). CONCLUSIONS: Analysis of the 1988-2003 SEER data indicated that extirpation of the primary breast tumor in patients with stage IV disease was associated with a marked reduction in risk of dying after controlling for variables associated with survival. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17687611 Fields RC, et al. Surgical resection of the primary tumor is associated with increased long-term survival in patients with stage IV breast cancer after controlling for site of metastasis.  Annals of Surgical Oncology 2007;14:3345-3351. Chart review (Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO) identified 409 patients with stage IV breast cancer treated from 1996 to 2005; 187 received surgical excision of their primary tumor and 222 did not. 102 patients had bone-only metastases, 281 had metastases to other organs +/- bone, and 26 had no metastases recorded. RESULTS: After controlling for age, comorbidity, tumor grade, histology, and sites of metastasis, patients who underwent surgical resection had longer median survival when compared with patients who did not undergo surgical resection (31.9 vs. 15.4 months, p < 0.0001; aHR 0.53 [95% CI 0.42-0.67]). CONCLUSIONS: Surgical excision of the primary breast tumor was associated with significantly longer survival in this cohort of stage IV breast cancer patients, even after controlling for other factors associated with survival. Randomized clinical trials are needed to validate these findings. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17687611 Blanchard DK, et al. Association of surgery with improved survival in stage IV breast cancer patients. Annals of Surgery 2008;247:732-738. Using a large database (Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX) of women who presented with stage IV breast cancer, we compared outcome of patients who had resection of their primary cancer to those who did not. METHODS: Of 16,401 patients, 807 had stage IV disease at presentation, and 395 survived >90 days and were included in this analysis. Clinical and tumor characteristics, surgical treatment, and survival were compared for the surgically versus nonsurgically treated patients. Two hundred and forty-two patients (61.3%) had definitive surgery for their primary tumor and 153 (38.7%) did not. Patients who underwent surgery were significantly older, were more likely to be white, more often had hormone receptor positive disease, had small primary tumors, and had fewer metastatic sites and less visceral involvement. The median survival of surgically treated patients was 27.1 months versus 16.8 months for patients without surgical resection (P < 0.0001). In multivariate analysis, which included surgical treatment, age, race, estrogen and progesterone receptor status, number of metastatic sites, and presence of visceral metastases, surgery remained an independent factor associated with improved survival (P = 0.006). CONCLUSION: Patients with stage IV breast cancer who had definitive surgical treatment of their primary tumors had more favorable disease characteristics. However, after adjustment for these characteristics, surgical treatment remained an independent factor associated with improved survival. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18357493 Rao R, et al. Timing of surgical intervention for the intact primary in stage IV breast cancer patients. Annals of Surgical Oncology 2008;15:1696-702. BACKGROUND: Recent studies demonstrate improved progression-free survival (PFS) and improved overall survival (OS) with extirpation of the primary tumor in breast cancer patients who present with metastatic disease at initial diagnosis. The subset of patients who would most benefit from surgery remains unclear. This study evaluates the pathological attributes and optimum timing for surgery in patients who present with stage IV breast cancer and an intact primary. METHODS: Retrospective, single-institution (University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas) review of all breast cancer patients between 1997 and 2002 presenting with an intact tumor and synchronous metastatic disease. Information collected included: demographics, tumor characteristics, metastatic sites, type/timing of surgery, and radiation/systemic therapy received. Patients initiated treatment within 3 months of their diagnosis. Patients were divided into three groups based on time interval from diagnosis date to surgery date. Disease progression and vital status at last follow-up were evaluated. Analysis of metastatic PFS (defined by progression of systemic disease) benefit in relation to surgical timing was performed. RESULTS: Multivariate analysis revealed patients having only one site of metastasis, negative margins, and Caucasian race had improved PFS. Further analysis revealed non-Caucasian patients more often underwent surgical intervention for palliation versus surgery for curative intent, possibly explaining their worse outcome. Patients who underwent surgery in the 3-8.9 month or later period had improved metastatic PFS. CONCLUSIONS: Surgical extirpation of the primary tumor in patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improved metastatic PFS when performed more than 3 months after diagnosis. Resection should be planned with the intent of obtaining negative margins.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 12:14PM AnnNYC wrote: RedWeasel, that sounds so awful!  I'm so sorry! I had a seroma between excisional biopsy (equivalent to a small lumpectomy) and eventual mastectomy -- it didn't burst, but it was very painful, and I think it developed in part because I immediately went back to work, and even worked an all-nighter 2 weeks after biopsy/lumpectomy. I also had mastitis several times while nursing my son, 25 years ago.  The mastitis was DEFINITELY related to poor nutrition -- I got it 3 times, and each time was after a crazy day where I went 8 or 10 hours without eating -- NOT something to do when you're nursing! Anyway -- I'm glad you came here -- don't apologize!  And just because you don't have BC doesn't mean you don't need special treatment!  Mastitis is no joke, and healing from surgery isn't either.  I imagine in your job you do some lifting?  I really hope you can take it as easy as possible -- maybe get a little extra time off? Just generally, healing from surgery and/or infection/inflammation requires good nutrition and plenty of good rest. Protein, vitamins, lots of water, lots of good nights' sleep, NO LIFTING! Here's a little post-surgery nutrition info: http://www.hss.edu/24217.htm I hope others will be along with more advice, but I just want to give (((gentle hugs))) and hopes that you'll be on the mend soon, Ann

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 10:32AM AnnNYC wrote: Stephanie, I know there are women on this board with diabetes who have had chemo. According to this (UK) website http://www.cancerhelp.org.uk/help/default.asp?page=4190, there just has to be careful planning and monitoring of blood sugar and food consumed. Another study I found observed 238 chemo patients, half with diabetes and half without.  The patients with diabetes did not have more complications from chemo than the other group. Best, Ann [P.S. Slightly off topic: Something interesting is that the diabetes drug Avandia (rosiglitazone) made platinum chemo drugs MORE EFFECTIVE in lab tests (human cells lines, and in mice). http://www.news.harvard.edu/gazette/2007/05.10/03-diabetes.html I don't think they have started testing this in people yet, but they are looking into it.  I guess it's not directly about chemo in people with diabetes, but still exciting -- and I do wonder whether a diabetic patient doing well on chemo was what made the researchers look at this in the first place?]

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 02:19PM AnnNYC wrote: Marian, I had a mass at the edge of my areola.  I felt it -- it couldn't be seen on mammo or ultrasound.  I had a fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy that was "inconclusive."  So my breast surgeon recommended an excisional biopsy, where they remove the whole lump for pathology.  They removed a 1-cm lump, turned out to be cancer, didn't get "clean margins" -- the "dirty" side involved  my areola and nipple.  My breast surgeon recommended mastectomy -- saying that the whole point of a lumpectomy (and thus having to undergo radiation for sure) is to have a good cosmetic outcome, which I wouldn't have if nipple and areola were removed.  I totally know what you mean about "it's the only part of the breast that matters."  I had the mastectomy, and reconstruction with a tissue expander followed by silicone implant. I too think that there ought to be some way for them to get a definitive biopsy before proceeding to remove your nipple and areola -- and that if the definitive biopsy is not benign, then mastectomy might actually be more reasonable than a "lumpectomy" that removes nipple and areola.  But I agree that it seems someone should be able to give you a definitive diagnosis first. I will say that 4 cm by 2 cm does not sound small to me. Also, the kind of ultrasound-guided biopsy you had (a core biopsy, maybe?) can miss the lump it is trying to sample -- unfortunately.  I don't know how common it is, but it did happen to a good friend of mine, whose doctor also wrote something that in effect said "sampled tissue benign, but I still think it's cancer" -- and it was.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2009 09:51AM AnnNYC wrote: Frilly, I don't know if I have any ideas about your pain, but I just wanted to make sure your post was answered -- and maybe "bump" it back up to the top where someone who has more ideas might see it. I do think you should pay attention to your own gut feeling about this.  If it doesn't feel like your fibromyalgia, you should keep pushing for an explanation.  Like I said already, others may know more about this than I do, but I do believe that lobular breast cancer (ILC) is much harder to "see" on a mammogram than ductal breast cancer (IDC).  A clear mammogram does not necessarily mean everything's fine -- an MRI might be the next step if your pain persists. Also, there is a type of breast cancer called inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) that can best be diagnosed by a "punch" biopsy of some of the skin of the breast.  It doesn't start with a lump, and isn't typically seen on a mammogram.  Typically it has other symptoms besides pain, like a red rashy or bruised appearance, an increase in size of the breast, feelings of heaviness and/or heat and/or itching, dimpling or pitting of the breast skin.  I hesitate to bring it up -- maybe I'm way off base in mentioning it -- but on the other hand, I just think an intense pain like yours merits attention.  Can you get a referral to a breast specialist?  I think that would be the best thing to do.

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 09:32AM AnnNYC wrote: Stephanie, I looked at the link to the trial and saw that it is a Phase I trial.  This means it's a very new treatment for this purpose, really among the first trials in people to see whether lithium protects the brain during radiation. Before a Phase I study can be started, there have been test-tube and animal studies that show strong reason to believe this will work in people. In the case of lithium, it is not a new drug, as it has been used for more than 50 years to treat bipolar disorder.  So more is understood about the risks of lithium, the adverse effects and what is an excessive dose.  The researchers are starting off with more knowledge than they do in many other Phase I studies.  But the knowledge that is missing is how well it will work to protect the brain from radiation toxicity.  From reading the study description, and looking online for other studies (I found studies showing that it works in mice), it looks to me like this Vanderbilt study is really the first -- probably the only people with experience would be anyone already in this Vanderbilt study. Have they given you an informed consent form to read, to help you decide about the trial?

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 01:26AM AnnNYC wrote: FightnF8, have a wonderful time! As my name suggests, I live in NYC (East Village, Manhattan) -- grew up in small town central Wisconsin, and have given lots of "tours" to my family coming to visit. There is so much to do -- just do as much as you want!  I second everyone's wonderful suggestions here -- the free Staten Island ferry gives you a great view of the Statue of Liberty -- if one of your days here turns out to be hot, that's a good day for the ferry! The unlimited MetroCard is a good idea -- besides the subway, they work on buses too (I'm a big fan of city buses anyway, and especially for people who want to see the city).  I love Carmine's, and John's Pizza is great -- if you get down to Greenwich Village, the original John's is really charming (http://www.johnsbrickovenpizza.com/).  Katz's Deli is in my neck of the woods -- but really, there are great restaurants everywhere.  One I discovered when my brother and SIL were visiting is Becco, in the Theater District on 46th Street between 8th and 9th Avenues (http://becco-nyc.com/#13056091572521&true) -- it's one of Lidia Bastianich's restaurants.  (Obviously, I figure no one can ever have too much Italian food!) The food court in the lower level of Grand Central Station is really great.  AND the Eneslow shoe store!  Don't know how you feel about churches, but whenever I'm around St. Patrick's Cathedral (5th Avenue between 50th & 51st Streets) on a weekday afternoon, I love to step in for a few minutes.  It's a block east of Rockefeller Center (6th Ave, 47th to 50th Streets) -- so that's a little sightseeing jaunt...  And if you don't make it down to Greenwich Village, the Magnolia Bakery now has a shop in Rockefeller Center AND Grand Central Station! (http://www.magnoliabakery.com/find_us_new_york.php) Have a wonderful time!

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2009 08:57AM AnnNYC wrote: Chantel, you are such a good daughter -- and it is completely appropriate for you to join this site to help your mother.  Many daughters, sons, spouses, partners, siblings -- and parents of women with breast cancer -- have joined this site to help the person they love.  The number one thing you can do is stay in touch and be as "normal" as possible for your mom.  Ask her if she would like you to come along to any of her doctor visits/treatments (if you live close enough to do so, and have the time).  You say she is independent, but she may appreciate the company (and extra ears to take notes, and extra pair of arms to carry things, etc.).  In general, I think you can take your cues from her -- sometimes she will want to tell you what's going on, sometimes she will want you to give her a "break" from this process and just talk about what's going on in your life. Sometimes, it's a fine line for a loved one to walk, between being worried and optimistic -- as much as you can, it's best just to listen and empathize and say you're there for her, for whatever she wants or needs.  (Not to tell her what she should be feeling! but I don't get the sense you're the kind of person who would do that, anyway!) If she is online at all, she may want to join this site herself -- but not everybody wants to do that. I'm sure others will come along who can express this better, or offer more specifics, but I just wanted to let you know you are very welcome to be here -- I'm so sorry that you have to be, but you've come to the right place. My best to you and your mom, Ann
