Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 08:16PM AnnNYC wrote: Hi otter, I wonder if some of the push for lumpectomy on the part of the doctors has a nonmedical reason: generally, the U.S. South has been behind the curve, performing more mastectomies and fewer lumpectomies compared to the Northeast.  Maybe your doctors are more concerned about being seen as "cutting-edge" and "enlightened" than they are about your preferences.  But YOU are also enlightened.  You've worked in a health field. You'd rather not have radiation, if possible.  Survival rates are equivalent but some recurrence rates are higher for lumpectomy than mastectomy.  Even the big paper (http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/347/16/1233) that is the basis for the National Cancer Institute's statement that lumpectomy and mastectomy are equivalent for early, small tumors, says that  "Lumpectomy followed by breast irradiation continues to be appropriate therapy for women with breast cancer, provided that the margins of resected specimens are free of tumor and an acceptable cosmetic result can be obtained." I added the emphasis.  That sentence strongly implies what my breast surgeon said to me -- the reason for doing a lumpectomy is to retain a breast that has an acceptable appearance.  That's why doctors and patients accept the need for radiation tx, and the greater risk of local recurrence.  If the lump to be removed is big and the breast is small, that's a frequent and entirely valid reason for choosing mastectomy.  Need (and inability) to travel a great distance for rads tx is another frequent and valid reason to opt for mast instead of lumpectomy. I had an excisional biopsy first, but it didn't have clean margins.  Nipple was involved, so surgeon strongly recommended mastectomy, which I had in April 2007.  Knock on wood - so far, so good.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 12:29AM - edited Jun 25, 2008 05:57PM by AnnNYC worriedhubby -- I can't really answer your first question, and I'm not someone who has "already been through chemo" -- but my Oncotype score was 16, and I didn't do chemo, so I would say most people agree chemo is not worth it when score is 11.   In fact, there is a clinical trial called the TailoRx trial, to see what the outcomes are with and without chemo for the various Oncotype scores -- and with a score of 10 or below, NO ONE in the trial gets chemo.  So the designers of the trial, and more importantly, the ethics board that approved it, feel it is safe for women with a score of 10 or below not to have chemo.  And 11 is very, very close!  Clearly, I wouldn't do chemo -- because I didn't with a score of 16!  Best, Ann

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 06:21PM - edited Feb 27, 2008 06:22PM by AnnNYC My hypothesis runs more along the lines that LisaSDCA is thinking of -- autoimmunity represents a case of a hyperactive, hypervigilant immune system.  An immune system that might be more likely to isolate and kill cancer cells than to let them proliferate.  As for autoimmune symptoms receding during chemotherapy -- that makes total sense.  In fact, a lot of chemotherapy drugs are used (usually in much smaller doses) to treat autoimmune diseases: oral low-dose methotrexate (the "M" in CMF) is pretty much standard care for rheumatoid arthritis, and cytoxan/cyclophosphamide (the "C" in CMF) is used when lupus is threatening the kidneys.  A lot of the studies monitoring the incidence of cancer among people with autoimmune disease are based on the idea that immunosuppression presents a risk to develop cancer, and immunosuppressive drugs are often prescribed to treat autoimmune disease: prednisone, or the new biologic agents (monoclonal antibodies) like Humira (adalimumab). ???

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2008 09:16PM AnnNYC wrote: sunflower45, It's good that you're getting this checked out, and I know how scary this can be. I just want to say that when it comes to evaluating lumps, all tools should be used -- mammogram, hands-on exam, ultrasonography, biopsy -- in order to get a definitive answer.  There aren't hard-and-fast rules about how a breast cancer feels, how fast it grows, whether it will be seen on a mammogram or not. Mammograms can see some things we can't feel -- but they can't see everything, unfortunately. There is no one perfect tool. I know that's not the most reassuring answer -- but I think it is very important to follow this up to get a definitive answer -- which is what you are doing.  It's said that 80% of biopsies are benign, so I hope you can just reassure yourself that you are taking good care of yourself by checking this out.  If your anxiety is getting the upper hand, please do whatever you need to make yourself feel better, including asking your doctor for an anti-anxiety medication or something to help you sleep. Keeping my fingers crossed for benign results for you, Ann

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 07:18AM - edited Aug 25, 2008 07:21AM by AnnNYC Hi Annie, I think there's a HUGE range of normal.  Some women have drains out 5 days after bilat. Mine was in for 4 weeks after unilateral mx, and NEVER got down to the fabled "30 cc for two days in a row." (My surgeon took it out at 4 weeks when it had been bouncing between 35 and 50 for a week, and said that some people continue to generate fluid in response to the presence of the tube/drain, so if it hadn't gotten down to 30cc/day by 4 weeks, it might never!  I was fine after they finally pulled it.) I did notice that the more active I was, the more fluid drained out -- and I think some of that was more fluid being generated, though I'm just guessing about that...  But 75 or 80cc five days after surgery sounds completely normal. P.S.  Four weeks is WAY out on the far end of the bell curve, and I hope and pray that you are on the "near" side, or at least somewhere in the middle (2 weeks, I think)!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 09:56AM - edited Mar 30, 2009 12:30PM by AnnNYC Hi Kibbles, There are some kinds of childhood radiation exposure that do increase the risk of breast cancer, but I think they mostly involve women who underwent radiation treatments as children (for example, treatments for Hodgkins disease, lymphoma, thymus disorders). Radiotherapy involves much greater exposure than diagnostic x-rays.  Also, women who in girlhood had scoliosis that was monitored with x-rays over many years (particularly in the 1950s or earlier, as Linda said above) do seem to have an increased risk for breast cancer. Here is an article from Cornell University that I think explains the breast-cancer-risk of radiation pretty well: http://envirocancer.cornell.edu/factsheet/physical/fs52.radiation.cfm One thing it says is that the age at exposure makes a difference.  I do think that you should mention your x-ray exposure to a doctor when you're having a breast exam.  A doctor who specializes in breast health, even an ob-gyn, should be able to put this into context for you. But, from my reading of the article, I think it supports what Barbe and Linda said -- your exposure to diagnostic x-rays for one infection is probably not the kind of exposure that puts you in a higher risk category for breast cancer. Best, Ann

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2008 02:51PM - edited Jul 24, 2008 02:55PM by AnnNYC rockthebald, Most hospitals in NYC are supplied by the New York Blood Center, an "independent, non-profit, community-based" blood bank with an excellent reputation. The biggest problem in NYC, which is a problem everywhere, is supply -- which is usually lowest in the summer.  You could certainly ask friends and family to donate for you -- especially if you have an unusual blood type -- it's also generous to just donate to the Blood Center on general principle.  The NYBC charges a fee and requires a doctor's prescription/plan for "autologous or directed donation" -- and they also say "there is no evidence that blood from donors selected by patients is safer than blood from the volunteer blood supply." Anyway -- they are excellent, in my experience.  They were in the forefront of safety with regard to AIDS/HIV, way out in front in that field. The American Red Cross has been having some trouble with their blood banking lately (as in this story from last week's New York Times, which prompted this letter from the head of the NYBC suggesting the ARC might do better to break up its Blood Bank division into, say, 5 autonomous smaller regional units...).

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 12:00PM AnnNYC wrote: Orli, I'm surprised that your onc is so dismissive of your history of systemic lupus.  In everything I read about radiation recommendations, SLE and scleroderma are mentioned as possible reasons NOT to recommend radiation. I too am a little confused about your dx; as Cheryl Rubie said,  <1 cm with no affected nodes would appear to be Stage I.  Where I differ with CherylRubie is that I don't think Grade 2 automatically means you should have radiation.  As far as I know, Grade 2 is intermediate, Grade 3 would be more likely aggressive. Radiation has been standard with lumpectomy, but there are studies ongoing to evaluate results of lumpectomy without rads for early-stage BC. On the other hand, women with lupus who have more advanced BC have undergone rads successfully. RubyTuesday is right -- ask for all your pathology reports, and get a second opinion.  Also -- do you see a rheumatologist regularly for your lupus?  This might also be someone with experience and helpful opinions, who has seen other SLE patients treated for cancer, and might have a recommendation for an oncologist who "works and plays well" with your rheumatologist!

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 01:01PM AnnNYC wrote: Alpal, maybe that doctor was talking about people in a nonradioactive area drinking milk from cows in a radioactive area?  Because radioactive iodine is certainly in the atmosphere after a nuclear accident or explosion, and humans can inhale it or ingest it (because it quickly dissolves in water, remaining radioactive) just like cows can. [http://www.epa.gov/radiation/radionuclides/iodine.html] And according to this news story, "The Pentagon also confirmed some flight crews [U.S. military in Japan] were issued with potassium iodide tablets to combat the possible effects of radiation." And SherrySt, "meltdown" is often used in the press as synonymous with "partial meltdown."  A meltdown is a process on a continuum from partial to full, and a lot of news reports are referring to the Fukushima meltdown(s).  "Meltdown" is an informal term, not a scientific or technical term. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_meltdown]

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 10:26AM AnnNYC wrote: Inlimbo, I was knocked out for excisional biopsy of a 1-cm tumor, so I'm sure they'll knock you out.  I think I was in the OR for 45 minutes.  Then they kept me in the recovery room a little longer than expected because my blood pressure remained low.  But still, I think I left by 1 pm (8 am surgery).  At that time, I felt no pain except whenever the cab I rode home in went over a pothole.  I had very exact instructions about what to do and NOT to do in the next 24 hours, 48 hours, 7 days.  I was told to wear a snug-fitting bra for the next week.  I didn't have a lot of pain (except for my nipple, because tumor involved edge of nipple, but if yours is far away from nipple that should be different). It was not a terribly big deal... BUT... don't let anybody push you beyond your endurance.  I had a horrible boss at the time, a woman physician, who thought if you were able to sit up, you were able to sit up and work for her for 24 hours straight.  I had the biopsy on a Friday morning -- she was upset that I didn't come to work on Friday afternoon! -- and I didn't take any other time off.  I was expected to continue 10-hour days, and compelled to do an all-nighter on a grant deadline 2 weeks after biopsy, and I developed a painful seroma (collection of fluid under the incision). So -- I'm saying it's not a huge deal -- but don't let that fact allow people around you to treat you like it's NOTHING, either! I imagine you will also have more healing to do as your tumor is 4 cm compared to my 1 cm. Best of luck to you, and try to arrange things to make it easy on yourself! Ann

Posts.Content: May 21, 2011 01:52AM - edited May 21, 2011 02:01AM by AnnNYC Okay, I just looked up some Elsevier medical textbook info on fainting from low blood pressure ("syncope") and it says: "Sometimes after fainting, muscle twitching occurs." So there!  You passed out from low blood pressure!  Hope your transfusion isn't TOO icky, and it helps you feel a lot better. (((((((((((hugs))))))))))))) Edit to add my nerdy scientific thought: I think the twitching response may be the body's attempt to restore proper blood pressure by signaling nerves to trigger little muscle contractures in order to constrict the blood vessels -- narrow the "hose" and then the same volume of blood will travel further, faster -- all kinds of little nerve signals go back and forth, trying to get us back on our feet!

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 07:33PM - edited Jan 4, 2008 07:36PM by AnnNYC Hi Jacqui, I'm not needle-phobic, but I was definitely surgery-phobic and anesthesia-phobic.  But I just had to do it.  Each time I woke up and realized that I'd survived the surgery & anesthesia, I was a little less panicky for the next one... I do think I'm extra-sensitive bordering on jumpy.  Or maybe everybody is this sensitive but the people with needles like to act like I'm crazy!?  I had an MRI-guided biopsy, and the doctor told me not to move and then injected my breast with a needle that I didn't see coming -- and my body involuntarily jerked 2 inches off the MRI table -- the doc was furious!  I thought that was nuts of her.  No one ever told me about numbing cream, but for every breast injection after that MRI (including injection of the dye for the sentinel node biopsy or SNB) I asked the person with the needle to lay the point of the needle on my skin and then wait for me to say "okay" before pushing it in.  This way my body was prepared and didn't fly off the chair, bed or table.  I don't know if this would help you -- but it has helped me a lot, since for me it's not my brain but my body that goes nuts when hit by an intense sensation (er, pain!) that it was unprepared for. I would echo what Sally and Deb said: tell all your doctors and their nurses/assistants how you feel about needles and procedures.  Maybe one of them might even refer you to a behavioral therapist -- the kind who help people through other phobias, using desensitizing techniques?  Maybe you won't have the time for this, but some medical centers now have "prepare for surgery -- heal faster" relaxation and stress-reduction classes, and might be enlightened enough to have someone on staff who knows techniques to help desensitize people to their phobias. About people bursting into tears -- that is a tough one.  I only had two of those (one of my sisters, one of my best friends), but two was enough -- made me wary about when and how I told people, and who I told -- I didn't want to have to worry about drying any MORE tears.  I hope you have one person around you who is saying "I won't let anything bad happen to you, I'll make sure you're okay" -- my boyfriend said that and it was wonderful.  We both knew it was kind of "magical thinking" -- but it worked its magic!  I love him for not letting on that he was scared.  I know he WAS scared, but he really knew to keep it under wraps and just tell me everything would be okay. If you don't have someone saying that -- maybe there is someone who will "obey" you and say it once you tell them to say it!  And then they can help you with the others who are crying.  You need someone to say "we'll get through this."  Because you will. You will. (P.S. Oh yes, we had some drinks -- me & my boyfriend and a bottle of tequila...)

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 01:16PM - edited Jul 29, 2009 01:17PM by AnnNYC I have to say, the lump near my nipple that turned out to be invasive ductal felt painful, warm to the touch, and appeared red on the surface.  The very words I used to describe it, over and over, were: "It feels like when I had an infection/clogged milk duct when I was nursing."  Everybody thought it was unlikely to be cancer, but thankfully they "put me through the paces" in a timely fashion, anyway: Diagnostic mammo and ultrasound -- nothing seen, but radiologist immediately referred me to breast surgeon for consult because "the nipple and areola are hard to visualize on mammo and ultrasound, and you have dense breasts." Breast surgeon first did fine needle aspiration (FNA) which showed "epithelial proliferation" but she felt it was inconclusive and advised excisional biopsy.  It was the excisional biopsy that showed IDC -- apparently a surprise to my breast surgeon (or she's a very good actress! very calming, while moving ahead to be sure of diagnosis!). Anyway, of course I don't want to alarm you, but I'd hate for your daughter to be falsely reassured and let this go -- I think it's always better to rule out BC than to "wait and see." Fingers crossed that all turns out to be benign -- hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 08:25PM AnnNYC wrote: Diane/badboob67, I wrote this whole long comment in answer to your question, and my computer swallowed it before I managed to post! Anyway -- I did a quick PubMed search and I found things that contradicated my "hypothesizing" above, although I didn't see any mention of breast cancer in the abstracts I read. This link -- http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16462517?ordinalpos=12&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_RVDocSum  -- is to a 2006 paper that says: "...studies show an increased risk for the development of lymphoma in rheumatoid arthritis. There are data suggesting an increased risk for rheumatoid arthritis patients regarding lung cancer. In Sjogren's syndrome-related malignancies, most publications in the past year relate to non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, and suggest possible mechanisms driving the association. Data substantiate an increased risk of certain cancers in systemic lupus erythematosus; the risk appears to be most heightened for lymphoma. A recent cohort study examined cancer risk in scleroderma; the estimates were lower than previous studies had suggested, and the confidence intervals relatively imprecise, making a definitive conclusion difficult." If anyone wants the full paper and can't get to it through the link, PM me. Best, Ann

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 04:57PM AnnNYC wrote: There was an article in the New York Times about hair donations last November: http://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/06/fashion/06locks.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=%22locks%20of%20love%22&st=cse&oref=slogin (you may have to register to read it, but registration is free) The article says Locks of Love only gives wigs to children, and mainly NOT to children with cancer but to children with alopecia areata ("an autoimmune disorder that destroys follicles and results in hair loss").  This 2007 article also says "Since the charity began in December 1997, it has provided about 2,000 wigs to recipients for free or a reduced price."  Yes, 2,000 wigs in 10 years. By contrast, the article says, "Pantene Beautiful Lengths, started in June last year [2006], has the resources of Pantene, the $3 billion global hair product division of Procter & Gamble, including teams of publicists who stage cutting fests. Already the program has received 18,000 ponytails - 8,000 more than originally projected - and distributed 2,000 wigs to women with cancer." http://www.beautifullengths.com/en_US/index_home.jsp http://www.beautifullengths.ca/ http://www.partagezvotrebeaute.ca/ More quotes: "As much as 80 percent of the hair donated to Locks of Love, the best known of the charities, is unusable for its wigs, the group says...  Even hair that survives the winnowing may not go to the gravely ill, but may be sold to help pay for charities' organizational costs." "Maggie Varney, a hairdresser and owner of a salon in St. Clair Shores, Mich., said she was shocked to learn that hair she collected from her clients and sent to Locks of Love was not used for wigs for children with cancer. In reaction, she formed her own nonprofit, Wigs 4 Kids, in 2003, which receives a few dozen donations of hair a month that are made into wigs that go predominantly to children with cancer." http://www.wigs4kids.org/ "Wigs for Kids, the oldest hair donation charity, was started more than 25 years ago by Jeffrey Paul, a designer and retailer of hairpieces. It receives 600 to 800 donations a month, he said, for wigs that usually go to children with cancer, but also to those with other medical conditions." http://www.wigsforkids.org/

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 11:09AM AnnNYC wrote: Treesie, The Oncotype Dx test is only valid for ER+ tumors.  It is all based on estimating how much EXTRA benefit ER+ women will get from chemo if they are also taking tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors.  Since you are "triple-negative" (ER-,PR-,HER2-), the Oncotype Dx would not be valid for you at all, and the tests and treatments you were given sound like the right thing for you, since chemo and surgery are the available weapons against triple-negative BC. Hugs, Ann

You should be given more information about your cancer before consenting to a mastectomy.  You should not have to go into surgery wondering whether it will be lumpectomy or mast.  If you are having mast, you should have the opportunity to consult with a plastic surgeon beforehand and arrange for immediate reconstruction to be performed in the same procedure, if that's what you choose. I don't see any reason for such speed -- except possibly in the case of inflammatory BC, which your description doesn't really fit, and which is quite rare -- which would be all the more reason to see a breast specialist.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 01:49AM - edited Feb 25, 2009 01:50AM by AnnNYC hope09, I was told by my surgeon to use an ice pack -- check with your surgeon for the timing.  Mine also told me to wear a snug-fitting sports bra "24/7 for two weeks" -- which I pretty much did. I also had mine on a Friday and was back to work on Monday.  [I hope you don't have to do too much lifting as a waitress -- I've worked in the kind of place where I had to carry a lot of heavy things myself -- that might not be the easiest work to go back to after 1 day off.  Hopefully, you can just take the orders and pour the coffee and maybe a busboy can help you with bigger trays, etc.] They gave me pain pills, but I think I only took 1 or 2 on the day of the biopsy itself (and mine was in a sensitive area next to nipple).  The thing that hurt the most was riding in a car going over potholes -- other than that, not bad. Most places have a list of instructions that you take home with you after the procedure (how long before you can shower, what signs to watch for that you should call the doctor about, etc.).  I always think it would have been nice if they'd given out those instructions a week ahead of time so you'd have a better idea what was happening! Wishing you the best, and benign results, Ann

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 03:24PM AnnNYC wrote: Robin, you had an invasive procedure only 2 weeks ago -- if there's a sudden marked change in color and texture to your breast, I would think the surgeon would be happy to at least listen to a description of its appearance.  Besides ruling out IBC (as Always Hope mentioned), I think you definitely want to rule out infection, or some kind of injury to a blood vessel, or to a nerve that could constrict a blood vessel. Don't be told you panic too much!  Your concerns are legitimate.  It never happened to you before, did it, that you woke up with half your breast a different color?  [What color, by the way? cherry red would indicate infection, bluish color would suggest venospasm (blood vessel or nerve problem) -- I'm not familiar with IBC except I know it has its own appearance changes] Waking up with the lower half of your breast a different color and texture -- combined with a recent procedure -- these are 2 out-of-the-ordinary things that may or may not be linked, but I would definitely call the surgeon's office with a description as my first step. I hope doctors evaluate you seriously and THEN tell you it's nothing!  But I don't see why you should tell YOURSELF it's nothing. Best of luck, Ann

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 12:31AM AnnNYC wrote: Hi Johnny, the "color doppler flow" shows blood flow speed and volume -- "vascularity" refers to blood vessels.  Increased rate and volume of blood flow is another sign that could mean cancer and should be checked out -- but, to quote a textbook about ultrasound in evaluating breast tumors, "color Doppler is useful in the assessment of tumor vascularity but is of limited value in the differentiation of benign from malignant lesions."  There are benign things that can cause abnormal blood flow. (I myself had "suspicious blood flow" on an MRI that turned out to be benign -- they were checking my right breast after finding cancer in the left -- so I know this can be very worrisome, but can turn out to be benign.) Wishing you and your wife benign news -- but, as Leaf and Virginia said, whatever the news, you will find a lot of support here.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 03:20PM - edited Jan 18, 2008 03:23PM by AnnNYC The only "chance" I would quote is that approximately 80% of breast biopsies are benign.  Beyond that, I would only say that you should see a doctor, tell them of your personal and family history, and go through the steps to find out what this lump is: mammogram, if not seen on mammo then ultrasound, and then whatever next steps follow from what is seen or not seen on the mammo or U/S, possibly fine needle aspiration or core biopsy. I think you'll feel better being proactive with a doctor -- your friends (and us, and your DOCTORS!) can talk about what it MIGHT be, but I think you probably really want to find out what it really IS.  Odds are high that it is benign, and I think the best thing is to KNOW that it is benign. Wishing you the best, Ann

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 03:40PM AnnNYC wrote: robyn33, My guess is that your husband has all kinds of thoughts and feelings about your diagnosis that he feels could overwhelm him -- and he doesn't want anyone to see or imagine him feeling these things!  I think that is at the root of what he's saying -- I also think it's possible he may never BELIEVE that's at the root of what he's saying -- he may cling to this "privacy" principle that has never been invoked before in your marriage -- For starters, I think it might be a good idea to calmly say that you -- and the family -- will need all the support you can get.  You will need to tell whoever you need to.  On the one hand, it is YOUR cancer, not his, and he should be following your lead and respecting your wishes.  On the other hand, it WILL affect your family -- and in my opinion you are taking the lead on that front, too -- I think it will help support your children if the other adults in their lives (like neighbors, teachers, coaches and in the case of your teenagers, UM, their FATHER!!!  who IS "family"!!!) know what they are going through. You are completely right about how we don't creep around in silence about other diseases -- which is why I think this is about your husband not wanting to experience the feelings he is faced with, and not wanting to be "seen" feeling them -- maybe he also has some more generalized old-fashioned idea that people don't talk about diseases of the breast, uterus, prostate, etc. --   but I hope he's not the kind of guy who is too hung up on being the "sole authority" in his family -- if he isn't usually authoritarian, I think you can just keep gently asserting the way you see things and the way you need to do things. (If it seems like he needs more help, or you need more help dealing with him -- your treatment center or hospital almost certainly have social workers specifically experienced in these kinds of cancer issues.)

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 02:56PM - edited Feb 11, 2009 02:57PM by AnnNYC I had an MRI-guided biopsy on a "suspiciously enhancing" area of my right breast (seen only on MRI). [I had IDC diagnosed in left breast by excisional biopsy, for which I needed mastectomy, and they wanted to make sure what was going on in right breast -- if cancer, they would have done bilateral mast.  The right turned out B9 despite "suspicious enhancement uptake kinetics."] It was like a regular MRI in that I lay face-down with my breasts hanging through little holes in the MRI table, and had contrast material injected by IV.  Then, the radiologist said, "I'm going to inject a local anesthetic, you'll feel a little pinch, don't move" and she jammed a needle into the side of my right breast and my whole body involuntarily jumped about 3 inches off the table!  The radiologist was really pissed at me!  And I, in turn, was pissed at her!  No numbing cream, no "countdown" to the injection, no hands on my back on the part of the TWO assistants alongside us!  That was the worst part for me, the anxiety over whether I still corresponded to the established "grid" after jumping -- frankly, 2 years later, I'm still not sure! -- and the doctor wondering out loud whether to quit the procedure and reschedule a week later, or forge ahead.  She forged ahead.  By then the anesthetic had taken effect, she put in some instrument that sounded like a dentist drill, got a big sample, I didn't feel any of this, there was a fair amount of bleeding and subsequent bruising, and I iced the hell out of my breast for the next two days, and wore a sports bra 24/7 for the next two weeks. In other words, to me, the most crucial part is before they anesthetize you for the procedure.  Ask for numbing cream, and what I have done ever since is ask the person with the needle to lay the tip of the needle to my skin, ask for my okay, and then count with me, "3, 2, 1, IN" -- this way I don't jump.  It is apparently essential that your body remain in the same "grid" mapped out by the MRI before the injection. Wishing you the best -- MRIs are hypersensitive and view as "suspicious" a lot of things that turn out to be benign.  Fingers crossed! Ann

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 05:18PM AnnNYC wrote: cwbagne, it is wrong to flatly state "chemo will likely do more harm than good" with an Oncotype score of 17. There is a clinical trial, the TAILORx Trial, going on right now to learn more about the risks and benefits of chemo versus "no chemo" for women whose Oncotype scores are between 11 and 25.  If your score is less than 11, you are assigned to take tamoxifen or an AI, and no chemo.  If your score is greater than 25, you are assigned to take chemo (followed by tamoxifen or an AI). If your score is from 11 through 25, you are randomly assigned to one of those two treatment regimens (tamoxifen or AI and no chemo; OR chemo followed by tamoxifen or AI). This trial started in 2006 and is scheduled to end in 2014.  If there was evidence that "chemo does more harm than good" in women with a score of 17, this trial would have to be stopped, or the protocol would have to be changed. Obviously, scores between 11 and 25 are in a classic "gray area" -- some women are almost literally "rolling the dice" by participating in a trial that chooses their treatment for them.  Others of us are making the best decision we can for ourselves.  I was 54, with a Grade 2 tumor, and a score of 16, and I chose "no chemo."  But even at my age, a Grade 3 would have made me more concerned, and if on top of Grade 3 I had been 37, like Yunlee is, I am pretty sure I would have chosen chemo.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 03:08AM AnnNYC wrote: I'm just scratching my head over Jane Plant's numbers.  She wrote: Only one in 10,000 women in China will die from it, compared to that terrible figure of one in 12 in Britain and the even grimmer average of one in 10 across most Western countries. In 1996, according to the World Health Organization, 3.5 women per 100,000 died of breast cancer per year in China, compared to 32.7 women per 100,000 per year in the U.S.  That difference is a factor of 10 -- not a factor of 1,000 as implied by Jane Plant's sentence above.  In 2004, the number of breast cancer deaths  in China had risen to 10 per 100,000 women per year -- compared to 30 deaths per 100,000 women per year in the U.S. -- a factor of 3. So it seems like Jane Plant's "1 in 10,000" is correct for China in 2004 -- but the "1 in 10" in Western countries is more like a lifetime incidence rate.  So it's mistaken and/or misleading (or even deceitful) of her to compare these numbers as if they're the same thing.  One in 10 (or 1 in 7) women in Western countries may be diagnosed with BC in their lifetimes (and more surveillance in Western countries may lead to higher diagnosis rates) -- but about 10 of 100,000 (1 in 10,000) women in China and 30 of 100,000 (3 in 1,000) women in the U.S. die of BC in a single year.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 03:22PM AnnNYC wrote: AA, I don't think there are.  If you click on that NCI article Luah linked to, you will see that it says it is expected that metronomic chemotherapy in breast cancer will most likely have a role in "indolent" ("lazy," slow-growing) cancers -- and would probably not be aggressive enough for aggressive, fast-growing cancers.  HER2+ is aggressive and fast-growing.  Institutional Review Boards (the ethics boards that need to approve clinical trials, and any research involving human subjects) are not likely to approve a trial in patients with aggressive cancers (TN, or HER2+) of a treatment that is thought not to be suited to aggressive cancers.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 10:10AM - edited Apr 27, 2009 10:15AM by AnnNYC Stacy, I'm a little more inclined towards your opinion than baywatcher's.  Perhaps an intermediate step that would satisfy you and your doctors is to ask for genetic testing for the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes (and maybe other breast-cancer related genes like "p53 mutation")?  I don't know how commonly such testing is done in the UK -- but it seems to me that if you were found to have genes that are known risks for breast, doctors would listen very differently to your interest in prophylactic bilateral mastectomy.  And if you were found NOT to have versions of genes that are known to be related to breast cancer, then you might find that some of your fears are eased.  I don't want to intensify your fears, or fan any flames here -- but I don't want to be falsely reassuring, either.  It's great to eat right, exercise, watch your weight -- but there are lots and lots of women on this board who have done exactly that yet developed breast cancer. To me, the logical first step would be genetic testing, and I hope you can get it. If you already KNOW your genetic information, or know that your mother had BRCA1 or BRCA2 -- then I think your doctors are being really dismissive. Maybe some women on this board who have had PBM will chime in -- I think most do NOT regret it. You might also find some helpful info on this website that is specifically for women with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer: http://www.facingourrisk.org/ Wishing you the best, Ann

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 08:49PM AnnNYC wrote: My take is different from LisaMG's, and more like Patoo's.  Being referred to a breast surgeon doesn't necessarily mean you're being referred for surgery.  It does mean your OB-GYN is not being dismissive of your inconclusive mammogram -- and that's a good thing, IMO. The breast surgeon (BS) may indeed order an ultrasound or MRI next -- or a fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy -- a good, experienced breast surgeon who specializes in breast cancer will go through diagnostic steps starting with the least invasive.  That type of breast surgeon is very often the "team leader" in arriving at a "real diagnosis" (which sometimes can't be established until a surgical biopsy is performed).  I agree -- breathe deeply -- I think it's far better for your OBGYN to err on the side of caution than to be dismissive -- and hopefully that is all this will turn out to be (erring on the side of caution). Hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 12:17PM AnnNYC wrote: In my case, I'd say cancer was the "bully" forcing me into a treatment I didn't want to do!  I am extremely surgery-phobic -- have avoided all kinds of semi-elective surgeries that would probably make my life a whole let better, including, to this point, cataract surgery (not really "elective" but not life-threatening enough to overcome my surgery fears of infection, bad outcome, reaction to anesthesia, etc.).  But with an almost 1-cm invasive tumor that was Grade 2, and growing into my nipple, I bit the bullet and had several surgeries -- lumpectomy, mastectomy, exchange... I'm just saying this as an example that sometimes a medical condition really forces us to undergo treatments we would prefer not to have!  And sometimes that requires a bit of a stern "talking-to" on somebody's part! As I was early stage, not triple-negative, not HER2+, and had an Oncotype score of 16 at age 54, chemo was not recommended, and I didn't have it.  (I had the perhaps unusual experience that this worried some of my friends, because we'd had a mutual friend who refused chemo 10 years earlier and had died -- but I tried to explain to my friends that she had likely been TN or HER2+.) But PatMom's comment reminded me of a dear friend on BCO who died in 2009 -- she was in her mid-30s when dx'd with very small TN tumor, and was not given chemo by her onc at the time.  When mets were discovered a few years later, she was so outraged that she had been told chemo wasn't necessary at her initial dx.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 12:25AM - edited May 2, 2008 12:26AM by AnnNYC Just wanted to clarify that MaryLynn said "MODIFIED radical mastectomy" -- not "radical mastectomy." Right here on bc.org it says that "Most women who have mastectomies today have modified radical mastectomies." (http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/surgery/mastectomy.jsp) "Modified radical mast" means "simple mast plus axillary dissection (removal of Level I and II -- but not Level III! -- axillary lymph nodes).  "Modified radical" does NOT remove muscle under the breast or chest wall muscle. I think more and more women are having sentinel node biopsy (SNB) instead of axillary dissection.  MaryLynn -- if your surgeon/hospital cannot provide SNB, can you go somewhere that does?  I agree that with a tumor <1 cm with no lympho-vascular invasion, you shouldn't have to have all armpit lymph nodes removed.  SNB is becoming more and more available, so maybe you can find a provider that will do simple mast plus SNB on the affected side? You can definitely change your mind about prophylactic mast on the right -- if you are having misgivings, you should heed them! (I am identifying with you, because I had .9 cm IDC in left breast, unclean margin after lumpectomy, then mastectomy with SNB of left, implant recon -- and kept the right breast, untouched.  Rather than removal of right breast -- can you get an MRI of the right breast, as Beesie recommended?  And if anything looks suspicious on MRI, biopsy it before consenting to bilateral mast?  That's what I did after cancer dx in left: MRI of right, biopsy of suspicious area, turned out to be B9, so kept the right breast.)

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 09:32PM AnnNYC wrote: Ulla, I hate when doctors can't remember who I am or what my story is!  At the very least, they should look at your chart to refresh their memory before you come in the room! If you want to speak to another doctor, I think that would be a great idea.  My recollection of starting tamoxifen is that my doctor told me to start with 10 mg every other day for a week (or two???), then 10 mg every day for a week, then 20 mg a day.  In fact, there seem to be reports that 10 mg/day or 10 mg every other day might be as effective as 20 mg/day to prevent recurrence. There is also the issue of genetic testing for the CYP2D6 alleles -- the gene that produces the liver enzyme CYP2D6, which is responsible for metabolizing tamoxifen into the active metabolite endoxifen, which is what provides the protection against BC.  About 7-10% of the population have two "null" alleles and are poor producers of CYP2D6 -- and therefore poor metabolizers of tamoxifen.  Apparently there is controversy about whether to test premenopausal women for this allele at all -- but if you are already having strong feelings about not taking tamoxifen, finding out how well your body metabolizes and uses this drug might be something you want to know. If you want me to send you some links about these studies, let me know. Hugs, Ann

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 10:57AM AnnNYC wrote: Dear Ulla, I'm sorry you had to be the mother to your family -- I'm hoping that soon they will recover from the shock of the news and adjust into being able to help take care of YOU.  I hope your mother is feeling better today. I have been trying to look up statistics for you, but most studies about tamoxifen are about Stages I and II.  What I found about Stage III women who already had mastectomy and chemo is a study in comparing tamoxifen-only versus tamoxifen plus radiation.  That study said, absolutely radiation reduces recurrence and increases survival, tamoxifen alone is not enough. An interesting study about patient use of the drug in the U.S. said women are more likely to continue taking tamoxifen if they feel included in the decision, feel they have enough input from their doctor, and are told about side effects in advance.  Women who don't get these things are more likely to stop taking tamoxifen. (Reminds me of an old Saturday Night Live Weekend Update joke: "as reported in the medical journal 'Duh'!"  )

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 01:32PM AnnNYC wrote: Sue, please call the hotline ASAP, even if your tx is supposed to be tomorrow.  Also, you MUST tell all these symptoms -- all the nosebleeds and bathroom bleeds, the dates and the frequency and the quantity -- to the nurses and onc at your clinical trial.  You are in a clinical trial -- these trials have (or SHOULD HAVE!) safety rules -- they should be going over a checklist of symptoms with you after one tx and before the next.  Also, months ago someone said "you must do your chemos because they are tailored to your situation" -- but that was before we knew you were in clinical trial.  In the trial, the treatments are tailored to the trial protocol, NOT to the individual patient.  Practically your only chance for individual tailoring will be to tell the onc and trial nurses what you are experiencing. You are so strong.  I can't imagine lifting cases of soda NOW, a year after mastectomy, much less during chemo. But please, call the hotline.  Maybe they can speak DIRECTLY to your onky for you? xoxox Ann

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 05:56PM - edited Dec 23, 2009 02:39PM by AnnNYC My follow-up schedule is much like Linda's (LRM216).  No scans (to avoid unnecessary radiation) -- if I had symptoms there would be scans -- blood work-up including tumor markers is now once a year (I think it was every 3 to 6 months in the first year or so).  I had left mastectomy, no rads or chemo (Oncotype Dx score of 16), have been taking Aromasin for 2-1/2 years.  Saw my onc every 3 months for the first year; every 4 months in second year; now, in my third year, every 6 months.  My BS has followed me on a similar schedule.  Yearly mammo and ultrasound of my right breast.  Yearly bone densitometry (DEXA scan) to see if Aromasin is causing osteopenia/osteoporosis.
Posts.Title: Follow up for Stage I's carcharm 1Lizzy

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2008 06:05PM - edited Sep 6, 2008 06:13PM by AnnNYC Spacebrit -- it sounds like your doc may be talking about the Oncotype Dx test on the genetics of your tumor -- this test on tumor genetics can give a likelihood of recurrence and how much benefit you would be likely to get from chemo. The tumor genetics are different from a blood DNA test. The blood DNA test for the BRCA gene tells if you have a known BRCA mutation that puts you at risk for breast or ovarian cancer, that you inherited from your parents and can pass along to your kids. Tumor genetics include "somatic" mutations that happened in your "body" cells (not passed on through inheritance) to turn them into cancer cells.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 10:32PM AnnNYC wrote: NYC in September ??!!  That is so exciting!!!!! The night John Lennon was shot, one of the bands I was in had a gig scheduled, at the Mudd Club in NYC.  We were all in a daze, bands and clubgoers.  Terrible. Princess Di did die on a Saturday -- it was on the night-time news.  I was very upset -- I remember leaving the house and walking, it was a mild summer night -- just walking and walking. 9/11 -- I had a Dr.'s appointment at 9:45 AM at Broadway and 91st Street -- I live in lower Manhattan.  At around 9 AM I was waiting for a bus at First Avenue and Houston Street (NancyD knows where this is) and I saw a huge plume of smoke -- I thought "that's a really big fire -- maybe it's in Chinatown" -- I asked other people waiting for the bus if they knew what the fire was, but they didn't.  Then at 14th Street I got on the L train (subway from the East to the West side of Manhattan) and a woman who got on the train with me said "Did you hear a plane flew into the World Trade Center?  A friend of mine works there and I hope he's okay."  At that point, I immediately thought some little private plane had a crazy accident -- she did too.  Then I switched from the L to the 2 or 3 train at 7th Avenue, and took the 2 uptown to 96th.  No talk of WTC.  But the minute I got off the subway uptown, chaos.  People saying a SECOND plane, and these were both jumbo jets.  Oh my God.  I get to my doctor's office and he's freaking out too.  Just heard on the news about the Pentagon, and at that point news reports (later said to be mistaken) about car bombs in Washington, DC.  Brief doctor visit!  (My ex-husband had been given novocaine for a dental procedure in Brooklyn, in an office with a view of the WTC, and he and his dentist SAW the first plane hit the first tower.  They both freaked out and decided not to continue, even though his mouth was already numb.)  So, about 10:30, I'm heading back down to my job (17th Street and Second Ave) from Bdwy and 91st.  It's of course a gorgeous day.  Buses are crowded and I'm so freaked, I figure I'll walk for a while.  Streets are full of people gathered around, listening to news on radios from the open doors of parked cars, vans.  My plan is to walk to 72nd and get the subway -- but when I get there, the subway is shut down.  I keep walking down Broadway.  At about 56th Street -- the David Letterman theater -- huge TVs in the lobby window are showing the collapse of the towers!  I am completely freaked -- it looks so surreal -- for a minute I wonder if people are making some sick broadcast joke, or if it's a news simulation/speculation -- I say to the people standing around "Did this really happen?"  Yes.  Oh my God. Now I think, I'll get on a bus around Times Square or 42nd Street -- but when I get there, no VEHICLES are being allowed below 42nd Street.  Police officers are saying there are reports of bombs in subway tunnels, parked cars near WTC.  I keep walking.  Around 28th Street, I start smelling the smoke.  Acrid.  About 25th, we see a wave of people covered in ash.  Most of us walking downtown stare silently at the ashen people walking uptown.  I see one young woman, tiny, in her 20s, no shoes, looking freaked, covered in ash.  I ask her very gently if there is anything I can do to help her -- cash, water -- she says, no, she's been given water, she has reached a friend, she has a place to go, but she says in a voice that is trying not to cry or scream -- "I could have died!  I thought I would die!" But she is now near her friend's house and insists she'll be okay. So, soon I get to work -- a hospital at 17th and 2nd -- gurneys and IVs and nurses and doctors are lined up at the front entrance -- we're not a trauma center but specialize in non-life-threatening joint injuries -- apparently there had already been a first wave of people needing treatment -- but that was the most tragic thing, that there was never a second wave. Anyway, I get up to my desk -- lots of emails from family in Midwest, friends in Texas, etc. -- I tell them I'm okay.  Phone service is nearly nonexistent.  My son had just started his freshman year of college about 40 miles outside the city -- we finally spoke late in the afternoon -- he said school was called off for the next few days, but I told him to stay put for at least 24 hours. So at the end of the day I headed to my apartment, where I live alone, below 14th Street -- there were National Guardsmen on every corner -- you could only walk below 14th if you showed ID with a home address below 14th.  No vehicles allowed at all.  Just as I was walking home, there was a freakout of police vehicles rushing to Con Edison power plant at 14th and Ave C/D.  Some (false) bomb threat.  That one really got my heart rate up.  There were so many false alarms that day, and the next few days.  I still wonder about that: crazy people, malicious people, paranoid people, overanxious people?  Or part of the attacks? A woman in my building was a security guard at WTC -- she survived the 1993 bombing, and 9/11, thank God -- her two kids were in high school -- downtown -- at the time, and kind of ran all over the place freaking out trying to find her -- but fortunately the whole family was physically okay.  Financially -- well, the Red Cross was far stingier with security guards going without pay than they were with stockbrokers.  This is true, and I'll never understand it. Okay, that was longwinded... But someone on this board lived right near the WTC and a piece of falling plane and building crashed into her building...  I can't imagine.
